102# Attempt to warn users who are importing Prefect 1.x attributes that they may
103# have accidentally installed Prefect 2.x
104
105PREFECT_1_ATTRIBUTES = [
106    "prefect.Client",
107    "prefect.Parameter",
108    "prefect.api",
109    "prefect.apply_map",
110    "prefect.case",
111    "prefect.config",
112    "prefect.context",
113    "prefect.flatten",
114    "prefect.mapped",
115    "prefect.models",
116    "prefect.resource_manager",
117]

119
120class Prefect1ImportInterceptor(importlib.abc.Loader):
121    def find_spec(self, fullname, path, target=None):
122        if fullname in PREFECT_1_ATTRIBUTES:
123            warnings.warn(
124                f"Attempted import of {fullname!r}, which is part of Prefect 1.x, while"
125                f" Prefect {__version__} is installed. If you're upgrading you'll need"
126                " to update your code, see the Prefect 2.x migration guide:"
127                " `https://orion-docs.prefect.io/migration_guide/`. Otherwise ensure"
128                " that your code is pinned to the expected version."
129            )
130
131
132if not hasattr(sys, "frozen"):
133    sys.meta_path.insert(0, Prefect1ImportInterceptor())

class allow_failure(prefect.utilities.annotations.BaseAnnotation[~T]): 
47class allow_failure(BaseAnnotation[T]):
48    """
49    Wrapper for states or futures.
50
51    Indicates that the upstream run for this input can be failed.
52
53    Generally, Prefect will not allow a downstream run to start if any of its inputs
54    are failed. This annotation allows you to opt into receiving a failed input
55    downstream.
56
57    If the input is from a failed run, the attached exception will be passed to your
58    function.
59    """

Wrapper for states or futures.

Indicates that the upstream run for this input can be failed.

Generally, Prefect will not allow a downstream run to start if any of its inputs are failed. This annotation allows you to opt into receiving a failed input downstream.

If the input is from a failed run, the attached exception will be passed to your function.

allow_failure(value)

Create new instance of BaseAnnotation(value,)

1397):
1398    """
1399    Decorator to designate a function as a Prefect workflow.
1400
1401    This decorator may be used for asynchronous or synchronous functions.
1402
1403    Flow parameters must be serializable by Pydantic.
1404
1405    Args:
1406        name: An optional name for the flow; if not provided, the name will be inferred
1407            from the given function.
1408        version: An optional version string for the flow; if not provided, we will
1409            attempt to create a version string as a hash of the file containing the
1410            wrapped function; if the file cannot be located, the version will be null.
1411        flow_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this flow; this name can
1412            be provided as a string template with the flow's parameters as variables,
1413            or a function that returns a string.
1414        retries: An optional number of times to retry on flow run failure.
1415        retry_delay_seconds: An optional number of seconds to wait before retrying the
1416            flow after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero.
1417        task_runner: An optional task runner to use for task execution within the flow; if
1418            not provided, a `ConcurrentTaskRunner` will be instantiated.
1419        description: An optional string description for the flow; if not provided, the
1420            description will be pulled from the docstring for the decorated function.
1421        timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for
1422            the flow. If the flow exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed.
1423            Flow execution may continue until the next task is called.
1424        validate_parameters: By default, parameters passed to flows are validated by
1425            Pydantic. This will check that input values conform to the annotated types
1426            on the function. Where possible, values will be coerced into the correct
1427            type; for example, if a parameter is defined as `x: int` and "5" is passed,
1428            it will be resolved to `5`. If set to `False`, no validation will be
1429            performed on flow parameters.
1430        persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this flow
1431            should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
1432            that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on
1433            the features being used.
1434        result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this flow.
1435            This value will be used as the default for any tasks in this flow.
1436            If not provided, the local file system will be used unless called as
1437            a subflow, at which point the default will be loaded from the parent flow.
1438        result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this
1439            flow for persistence. This value will be used as the default for any tasks
1440            in this flow. If not provided, the value of `PREFECT_RESULTS_DEFAULT_SERIALIZER`
1441            will be used unless called as a subflow, at which point the default will be
1442            loaded from the parent flow.
1443        cache_result_in_memory: An optional toggle indicating whether the cached result of
1444            a running the flow should be stored in memory. Defaults to `True`.
1445        log_prints: If set, `print` statements in the flow will be redirected to the
1446            Prefect logger for the flow run. Defaults to `None`, which indicates that
1447            the value from the parent flow should be used. If this is a parent flow,
1448            the default is pulled from the `PREFECT_LOGGING_LOG_PRINTS` setting.
1449        on_completion: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is
1450            completed. Each function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow
1451            run, and the final state of the flow run.
1452        on_failure: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run fails. Each
1453            function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the
1454            final state of the flow run.
1455        on_cancellation: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is
1456            cancelled. These functions will be passed the flow, flow run, and final state.
1457        on_crashed: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run crashes. Each
1458            function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the
1459            final state of the flow run.
1460        on_running: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is started. Each
1461            function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the current state
1462
1463    Returns:
1464        A callable `Flow` object which, when called, will run the flow and return its
1465        final state.
1466
1467    Examples:
1468        Define a simple flow
1469
1470        >>> from prefect import flow
1471        >>> @flow
1472        >>> def add(x, y):
1473        >>>     return x + y
1474
1475        Define an async flow
1476
1477        >>> @flow
1478        >>> async def add(x, y):
1479        >>>     return x + y
1480
1481        Define a flow with a version and description
1482
1483        >>> @flow(version="first-flow", description="This flow is empty!")
1484        >>> def my_flow():
1485        >>>     pass
1486
1487        Define a flow with a custom name
1488
1489        >>> @flow(name="The Ultimate Flow")
1490        >>> def my_flow():
1491        >>>     pass
1492
1493        Define a flow that submits its tasks to dask
1494
1495        >>> from prefect_dask.task_runners import DaskTaskRunner
1496        >>>
1497        >>> @flow(task_runner=DaskTaskRunner)
1498        >>> def my_flow():
1499        >>>     pass
1500    """

Decorator to designate a function as a Prefect workflow.

This decorator may be used for asynchronous or synchronous functions.

Flow parameters must be serializable by Pydantic.

Args: name: An optional name for the flow; if not provided, the name will be inferred from the given function. version: An optional version string for the flow; if not provided, we will attempt to create a version string as a hash of the file containing the wrapped function; if the file cannot be located, the version will be null. flow_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this flow; this name can be provided as a string template with the flow's parameters as variables, or a function that returns a string. retries: An optional number of times to retry on flow run failure. retry_delay_seconds: An optional number of seconds to wait before retrying the flow after failure. This is only applicable if retries is nonzero. task_runner: An optional task runner to use for task execution within the flow; if not provided, a ConcurrentTaskRunner will be instantiated. description: An optional string description for the flow; if not provided, the description will be pulled from the docstring for the decorated function. timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for the flow. If the flow exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed. Flow execution may continue until the next task is called. validate_parameters: By default, parameters passed to flows are validated by Pydantic. This will check that input values conform to the annotated types on the function. Where possible, values will be coerced into the correct type; for example, if a parameter is defined as x: int and "5" is passed, it will be resolved to 5. If set to False, no validation will be performed on flow parameters. persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this flow should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to None, which indicates that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on the features being used. result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this flow. This value will be used as the default for any tasks in this flow. If not provided, the local file system will be used unless called as a subflow, at which point the default will be loaded from the parent flow. result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this flow for persistence. This value will be used as the default for any tasks in this flow. If not provided, the value of PREFECT_RESULTS_DEFAULT_SERIALIZER will be used unless called as a subflow, at which point the default will be loaded from the parent flow. cache_result_in_memory: An optional toggle indicating whether the cached result of a running the flow should be stored in memory. Defaults to True. log_prints: If set, print statements in the flow will be redirected to the Prefect logger for the flow run. Defaults to None, which indicates that the value from the parent flow should be used. If this is a parent flow, the default is pulled from the PREFECT_LOGGING_LOG_PRINTS setting. on_completion: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is completed. Each function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the final state of the flow run. on_failure: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run fails. Each function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the final state of the flow run. on_cancellation: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is cancelled. These functions will be passed the flow, flow run, and final state. on_crashed: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run crashes. Each function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the final state of the flow run. on_running: An optional list of functions to call when the flow run is started. Each function should accept three arguments: the flow, the flow run, and the current state

Returns: A callable Flow object which, when called, will run the flow and return its final state.

Examples: Define a simple flow

>>> from prefect import flow
>>> @flow
>>> def add(x, y):
>>>     return x + y

Define an async flow

>>> @flow
>>> async def add(x, y):
>>>     return x + y

Define a flow with a version and description

>>> @flow(version="first-flow", description="This flow is empty!")
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     pass

Define a flow with a custom name

>>> @flow(name="The Ultimate Flow")
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     pass

Define a flow that submits its tasks to dask

>>> from prefect_dask.task_runners import DaskTaskRunner
>>>
>>> @flow(task_runner=DaskTaskRunner)
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     pass
@PrefectObjectRegistry.register_instances
class Flow(typing.Generic[~P, ~R]): 
 132@PrefectObjectRegistry.register_instances
 133class Flow(Generic[P, R]):
 134    """
 135    A Prefect workflow definition.
 136
 137    !!! note
 138        We recommend using the [`@flow` decorator][prefect.flows.flow] for most use-cases.
 139
 140    Wraps a function with an entrypoint to the Prefect engine. To preserve the input
 141    and output types, we use the generic type variables `P` and `R` for "Parameters" and
 142    "Returns" respectively.
 143
 144    Args:
 145        fn: The function defining the workflow.
 146        name: An optional name for the flow; if not provided, the name will be inferred
 147            from the given function.
 148        version: An optional version string for the flow; if not provided, we will
 149            attempt to create a version string as a hash of the file containing the
 150            wrapped function; if the file cannot be located, the version will be null.
 151        flow_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this flow; this name can
 152            be provided as a string template with the flow's parameters as variables,
 153            or a function that returns a string.
 154        task_runner: An optional task runner to use for task execution within the flow;
 155            if not provided, a `ConcurrentTaskRunner` will be used.
 156        description: An optional string description for the flow; if not provided, the
 157            description will be pulled from the docstring for the decorated function.
 158        timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for
 159            the flow. If the flow exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed.
 160            Flow execution may continue until the next task is called.
 161        validate_parameters: By default, parameters passed to flows are validated by
 162            Pydantic. This will check that input values conform to the annotated types
 163            on the function. Where possible, values will be coerced into the correct
 164            type; for example, if a parameter is defined as `x: int` and "5" is passed,
 165            it will be resolved to `5`. If set to `False`, no validation will be
 166            performed on flow parameters.
 167        retries: An optional number of times to retry on flow run failure.
 168        retry_delay_seconds: An optional number of seconds to wait before retrying the
 169            flow after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero.
 170        persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this flow
 171            should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
 172            that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on
 173            the features being used.
 174        result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this flow.
 175            This value will be used as the default for any tasks in this flow.
 176            If not provided, the local file system will be used unless called as
 177            a subflow, at which point the default will be loaded from the parent flow.
 178        result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this
 179            flow for persistence. This value will be used as the default for any tasks
 180            in this flow. If not provided, the value of `PREFECT_RESULTS_DEFAULT_SERIALIZER`
 181            will be used unless called as a subflow, at which point the default will be
 182            loaded from the parent flow.
 183        on_failure: An optional list of callables to run when the flow enters a failed state.
 184        on_completion: An optional list of callables to run when the flow enters a completed state.
 185        on_cancellation: An optional list of callables to run when the flow enters a cancelling state.
 186        on_crashed: An optional list of callables to run when the flow enters a crashed state.
 187        on_running: An optional list of callables to run when the flow enters a running state.
 188    """
 189
 190    # NOTE: These parameters (types, defaults, and docstrings) should be duplicated
 191    #       exactly in the @flow decorator
 192    def __init__(
 193        self,
 194        fn: Callable[P, R],
 195        name: Optional[str] = None,
 196        version: Optional[str] = None,
 197        flow_run_name: Optional[Union[Callable[[], str], str]] = None,
 198        retries: Optional[int] = None,
 199        retry_delay_seconds: Optional[Union[int, float]] = None,
 200        task_runner: Union[Type[BaseTaskRunner], BaseTaskRunner] = ConcurrentTaskRunner,
 201        description: str = None,
 202        timeout_seconds: Union[int, float] = None,
 203        validate_parameters: bool = True,
 204        persist_result: Optional[bool] = None,
 205        result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = None,
 206        result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = None,
 207        cache_result_in_memory: bool = True,
 208        log_prints: Optional[bool] = None,
 209        on_completion: Optional[
 210            List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]
 211        ] = None,
 212        on_failure: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 213        on_cancellation: Optional[
 214            List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]
 215        ] = None,
 216        on_crashed: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 217        on_running: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 218    ):
 219        if name is not None and not isinstance(name, str):
 220            raise TypeError(
 221                "Expected string for flow parameter 'name'; got {} instead. {}".format(
 222                    type(name).__name__,
 223                    (
 224                        "Perhaps you meant to call it? e.g."
 225                        " '@flow(name=get_flow_run_name())'"
 226                        if callable(name)
 227                        else ""
 228                    ),
 229                )
 230            )
 231
 232        # Validate if hook passed is list and contains callables
 233        hook_categories = [
 234            on_completion,
 235            on_failure,
 236            on_cancellation,
 237            on_crashed,
 238            on_running,
 239        ]
 240        hook_names = [
 241            "on_completion",
 242            "on_failure",
 243            "on_cancellation",
 244            "on_crashed",
 245            "on_running",
 246        ]
 247        for hooks, hook_name in zip(hook_categories, hook_names):
 248            if hooks is not None:
 249                if not hooks:
 250                    raise ValueError(f"Empty list passed for '{hook_name}'")
 251                try:
 252                    hooks = list(hooks)
 253                except TypeError:
 254                    raise TypeError(
 255                        f"Expected iterable for '{hook_name}'; got"
 256                        f" {type(hooks).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
 257                        f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
 258                        f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
 259                        " my_flow():\n\tpass"
 260                    )
 261
 262                for hook in hooks:
 263                    if not callable(hook):
 264                        raise TypeError(
 265                            f"Expected callables in '{hook_name}'; got"
 266                            f" {type(hook).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
 267                            f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
 268                            f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
 269                            " my_flow():\n\tpass"
 270                        )
 271
 272        if not callable(fn):
 273            raise TypeError("'fn' must be callable")
 274
 275        # Validate name if given
 276        if name:
 277            raise_on_name_with_banned_characters(name)
 278
 279        self.name = name or fn.__name__.replace("_", "-")
 280
 281        if flow_run_name is not None:
 282            if not isinstance(flow_run_name, str) and not callable(flow_run_name):
 283                raise TypeError(
 284                    "Expected string or callable for 'flow_run_name'; got"
 285                    f" {type(flow_run_name).__name__} instead."
 286                )
 287        self.flow_run_name = flow_run_name
 288
 289        task_runner = task_runner or ConcurrentTaskRunner()
 290        self.task_runner = (
 291            task_runner() if isinstance(task_runner, type) else task_runner
 292        )
 293
 294        self.log_prints = log_prints
 295
 296        self.description = description or inspect.getdoc(fn)
 297        update_wrapper(self, fn)
 298        self.fn = fn
 299        self.isasync = is_async_fn(self.fn)
 300
 301        raise_for_reserved_arguments(self.fn, ["return_state", "wait_for"])
 302
 303        # Version defaults to a hash of the function's file
 304        flow_file = inspect.getsourcefile(self.fn)
 305        if not version:
 306            try:
 307                version = file_hash(flow_file)
 308            except (FileNotFoundError, TypeError, OSError):
 309                pass  # `getsourcefile` can return null values and "<stdin>" for objects in repls
 310        self.version = version
 311
 312        self.timeout_seconds = float(timeout_seconds) if timeout_seconds else None
 313
 314        # FlowRunPolicy settings
 315        # TODO: We can instantiate a `FlowRunPolicy` and add Pydantic bound checks to
 316        #       validate that the user passes positive numbers here
 317        self.retries = (
 318            retries if retries is not None else PREFECT_FLOW_DEFAULT_RETRIES.value()
 319        )
 320
 321        self.retry_delay_seconds = (
 322            retry_delay_seconds
 323            if retry_delay_seconds is not None
 324            else PREFECT_FLOW_DEFAULT_RETRY_DELAY_SECONDS.value()
 325        )
 326
 327        self.parameters = parameter_schema(self.fn)
 328        self.should_validate_parameters = validate_parameters
 329
 330        if self.should_validate_parameters:
 331            # Try to create the validated function now so that incompatibility can be
 332            # raised at declaration time rather than at runtime
 333            # We cannot, however, store the validated function on the flow because it
 334            # is not picklable in some environments
 335            try:
 336                ValidatedFunction(self.fn, config={"arbitrary_types_allowed": True})
 337            except pydantic.ConfigError as exc:
 338                raise ValueError(
 339                    "Flow function is not compatible with `validate_parameters`. "
 340                    "Disable validation or change the argument names."
 341                ) from exc
 342
 343        self.persist_result = persist_result
 344        self.result_storage = result_storage
 345        self.result_serializer = result_serializer
 346        self.cache_result_in_memory = cache_result_in_memory
 347        self.on_completion = on_completion
 348        self.on_failure = on_failure
 349        self.on_cancellation = on_cancellation
 350        self.on_crashed = on_crashed
 351        self.on_running = on_running
 352
 353        # Used for flows loaded from remote storage
 354        self._storage: Optional[RunnerStorage] = None
 355        self._entrypoint: Optional[str] = None
 356
 357        module = fn.__module__
 358        if module in ("__main__", "__prefect_loader__"):
 359            module_name = inspect.getfile(fn)
 360            module = module_name if module_name != "__main__" else module
 361
 362        self._entrypoint = f"{module}:{fn.__name__}"
 363
 364    def with_options(
 365        self,
 366        *,
 367        name: str = None,
 368        version: str = None,
 369        retries: Optional[int] = None,
 370        retry_delay_seconds: Optional[Union[int, float]] = None,
 371        description: str = None,
 372        flow_run_name: Optional[Union[Callable[[], str], str]] = None,
 373        task_runner: Union[Type[BaseTaskRunner], BaseTaskRunner] = None,
 374        timeout_seconds: Union[int, float] = None,
 375        validate_parameters: bool = None,
 376        persist_result: Optional[bool] = NotSet,
 377        result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = NotSet,
 378        result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = NotSet,
 379        cache_result_in_memory: bool = None,
 380        log_prints: Optional[bool] = NotSet,
 381        on_completion: Optional[
 382            List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]
 383        ] = None,
 384        on_failure: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 385        on_cancellation: Optional[
 386            List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]
 387        ] = None,
 388        on_crashed: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 389        on_running: Optional[List[Callable[[FlowSchema, FlowRun, State], None]]] = None,
 390    ) -> Self:
 391        """
 392        Create a new flow from the current object, updating provided options.
 393
 394        Args:
 395            name: A new name for the flow.
 396            version: A new version for the flow.
 397            description: A new description for the flow.
 398            flow_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this flow; this name
 399                can be provided as a string template with the flow's parameters as variables,
 400                or a function that returns a string.
 401            task_runner: A new task runner for the flow.
 402            timeout_seconds: A new number of seconds to fail the flow after if still
 403                running.
 404            validate_parameters: A new value indicating if flow calls should validate
 405                given parameters.
 406            retries: A new number of times to retry on flow run failure.
 407            retry_delay_seconds: A new number of seconds to wait before retrying the
 408                flow after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero.
 409            persist_result: A new option for enabling or disabling result persistence.
 410            result_storage: A new storage type to use for results.
 411            result_serializer: A new serializer to use for results.
 412            cache_result_in_memory: A new value indicating if the flow's result should
 413                be cached in memory.
 414            on_failure: A new list of callables to run when the flow enters a failed state.
 415            on_completion: A new list of callables to run when the flow enters a completed state.
 416            on_cancellation: A new list of callables to run when the flow enters a cancelling state.
 417            on_crashed: A new list of callables to run when the flow enters a crashed state.
 418            on_running: A new list of callables to run when the flow enters a running state.
 419
 420        Returns:
 421            A new `Flow` instance.
 422
 423        Examples:
 424
 425            Create a new flow from an existing flow and update the name:
 426
 427            >>> @flow(name="My flow")
 428            >>> def my_flow():
 429            >>>     return 1
 430            >>>
 431            >>> new_flow = my_flow.with_options(name="My new flow")
 432
 433            Create a new flow from an existing flow, update the task runner, and call
 434            it without an intermediate variable:
 435
 436            >>> from prefect.task_runners import SequentialTaskRunner
 437            >>>
 438            >>> @flow
 439            >>> def my_flow(x, y):
 440            >>>     return x + y
 441            >>>
 442            >>> state = my_flow.with_options(task_runner=SequentialTaskRunner)(1, 3)
 443            >>> assert state.result() == 4
 444
 445        """
 446        new_flow = Flow(
 447            fn=self.fn,
 448            name=name or self.name,
 449            description=description or self.description,
 450            flow_run_name=flow_run_name or self.flow_run_name,
 451            version=version or self.version,
 452            task_runner=task_runner or self.task_runner,
 453            retries=retries if retries is not None else self.retries,
 454            retry_delay_seconds=(
 455                retry_delay_seconds
 456                if retry_delay_seconds is not None
 457                else self.retry_delay_seconds
 458            ),
 459            timeout_seconds=(
 460                timeout_seconds if timeout_seconds is not None else self.timeout_seconds
 461            ),
 462            validate_parameters=(
 463                validate_parameters
 464                if validate_parameters is not None
 465                else self.should_validate_parameters
 466            ),
 467            persist_result=(
 468                persist_result if persist_result is not NotSet else self.persist_result
 469            ),
 470            result_storage=(
 471                result_storage if result_storage is not NotSet else self.result_storage
 472            ),
 473            result_serializer=(
 474                result_serializer
 475                if result_serializer is not NotSet
 476                else self.result_serializer
 477            ),
 478            cache_result_in_memory=(
 479                cache_result_in_memory
 480                if cache_result_in_memory is not None
 481                else self.cache_result_in_memory
 482            ),
 483            log_prints=log_prints if log_prints is not NotSet else self.log_prints,
 484            on_completion=on_completion or self.on_completion,
 485            on_failure=on_failure or self.on_failure,
 486            on_cancellation=on_cancellation or self.on_cancellation,
 487            on_crashed=on_crashed or self.on_crashed,
 488            on_running=on_running or self.on_running,
 489        )
 490        new_flow._storage = self._storage
 491        new_flow._entrypoint = self._entrypoint
 492        return new_flow
 493
 494    def validate_parameters(self, parameters: Dict[str, Any]) -> Dict[str, Any]:
 495        """
 496        Validate parameters for compatibility with the flow by attempting to cast the inputs to the
 497        associated types specified by the function's type annotations.
 498
 499        Returns:
 500            A new dict of parameters that have been cast to the appropriate types
 501
 502        Raises:
 503            ParameterTypeError: if the provided parameters are not valid
 504        """
 505        args, kwargs = parameters_to_args_kwargs(self.fn, parameters)
 506
 507        if HAS_PYDANTIC_V2:
 508            has_v1_models = any(isinstance(o, V1BaseModel) for o in args) or any(
 509                isinstance(o, V1BaseModel) for o in kwargs.values()
 510            )
 511            has_v2_types = any(is_v2_type(o) for o in args) or any(
 512                is_v2_type(o) for o in kwargs.values()
 513            )
 514
 515            if has_v1_models and has_v2_types:
 516                raise ParameterTypeError(
 517                    "Cannot mix Pydantic v1 and v2 types as arguments to a flow."
 518                )
 519
 520            if has_v1_models:
 521                validated_fn = V1ValidatedFunction(
 522                    self.fn, config={"arbitrary_types_allowed": True}
 523                )
 524            else:
 525                validated_fn = V2ValidatedFunction(
 526                    self.fn, config={"arbitrary_types_allowed": True}
 527                )
 528
 529        else:
 530            validated_fn = ValidatedFunction(
 531                self.fn, config={"arbitrary_types_allowed": True}
 532            )
 533
 534        try:
 535            model = validated_fn.init_model_instance(*args, **kwargs)
 536        except pydantic.ValidationError as exc:
 537            # We capture the pydantic exception and raise our own because the pydantic
 538            # exception is not picklable when using a cythonized pydantic installation
 539            raise ParameterTypeError.from_validation_error(exc) from None
 540        except V2ValidationError as exc:
 541            # We capture the pydantic exception and raise our own because the pydantic
 542            # exception is not picklable when using a cythonized pydantic installation
 543            raise ParameterTypeError.from_validation_error(exc) from None
 544
 545        # Get the updated parameter dict with cast values from the model
 546        cast_parameters = {
 547            k: v
 548            for k, v in model._iter()
 549            if k in model.__fields_set__ or model.__fields__[k].default_factory
 550        }
 551        return cast_parameters
 552
 553    def serialize_parameters(self, parameters: Dict[str, Any]) -> Dict[str, Any]:
 554        """
 555        Convert parameters to a serializable form.
 556
 557        Uses FastAPI's `jsonable_encoder` to convert to JSON compatible objects without
 558        converting everything directly to a string. This maintains basic types like
 559        integers during API roundtrips.
 560        """
 561        serialized_parameters = {}
 562        for key, value in parameters.items():
 563            try:
 564                serialized_parameters[key] = jsonable_encoder(value)
 565            except (TypeError, ValueError):
 566                logger.debug(
 567                    f"Parameter {key!r} for flow {self.name!r} is of unserializable "
 568                    f"type {type(value).__name__!r} and will not be stored "
 569                    "in the backend."
 570                )
 571                serialized_parameters[key] = f"<{type(value).__name__}>"
 572        return serialized_parameters
 573
 574    @sync_compatible
 575    @deprecated_parameter(
 576        "schedule",
 577        start_date="Mar 2024",
 578        when=lambda p: p is not None,
 579        help="Use `schedules` instead.",
 580    )
 581    @deprecated_parameter(
 582        "is_schedule_active",
 583        start_date="Mar 2024",
 584        when=lambda p: p is not None,
 585        help="Use `paused` instead.",
 586    )
 587    async def to_deployment(
 588        self,
 589        name: str,
 590        interval: Optional[
 591            Union[
 592                Iterable[Union[int, float, datetime.timedelta]],
 593                int,
 594                float,
 595                datetime.timedelta,
 596            ]
 597        ] = None,
 598        cron: Optional[Union[Iterable[str], str]] = None,
 599        rrule: Optional[Union[Iterable[str], str]] = None,
 600        paused: Optional[bool] = None,
 601        schedules: Optional[List["FlexibleScheduleList"]] = None,
 602        schedule: Optional[SCHEDULE_TYPES] = None,
 603        is_schedule_active: Optional[bool] = None,
 604        parameters: Optional[dict] = None,
 605        triggers: Optional[List[Union[DeploymentTriggerTypes, TriggerTypes]]] = None,
 606        description: Optional[str] = None,
 607        tags: Optional[List[str]] = None,
 608        version: Optional[str] = None,
 609        enforce_parameter_schema: bool = False,
 610        work_pool_name: Optional[str] = None,
 611        work_queue_name: Optional[str] = None,
 612        job_variables: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None,
 613        entrypoint_type: EntrypointType = EntrypointType.FILE_PATH,
 614    ) -> "RunnerDeployment":
 615        """
 616        Creates a runner deployment object for this flow.
 617
 618        Args:
 619            name: The name to give the created deployment.
 620            interval: An interval on which to execute the new deployment. Accepts either a number
 621                or a timedelta object. If a number is given, it will be interpreted as seconds.
 622            cron: A cron schedule of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 623            rrule: An rrule schedule of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 624            paused: Whether or not to set this deployment as paused.
 625            schedules: A list of schedule objects defining when to execute runs of this deployment.
 626                Used to define multiple schedules or additional scheduling options such as `timezone`.
 627            schedule: A schedule object defining when to execute runs of this deployment.
 628            is_schedule_active: Whether or not to set the schedule for this deployment as active. If
 629                not provided when creating a deployment, the schedule will be set as active. If not
 630                provided when updating a deployment, the schedule's activation will not be changed.
 631            parameters: A dictionary of default parameter values to pass to runs of this deployment.
 632            triggers: A list of triggers that will kick off runs of this deployment.
 633            description: A description for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's
 634                description if not provided.
 635            tags: A list of tags to associate with the created deployment for organizational
 636                purposes.
 637            version: A version for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's version.
 638            enforce_parameter_schema: Whether or not the Prefect API should enforce the
 639                parameter schema for the created deployment.
 640            work_pool_name: The name of the work pool to use for this deployment.
 641            work_queue_name: The name of the work queue to use for this deployment's scheduled runs.
 642                If not provided the default work queue for the work pool will be used.
 643            job_variables: Settings used to override the values specified default base job template
 644                of the chosen work pool. Refer to the base job template of the chosen work pool for
 645            entrypoint_type: Type of entrypoint to use for the deployment. When using a module path
 646                entrypoint, ensure that the module will be importable in the execution environment.
 647
 648        Examples:
 649            Prepare two deployments and serve them:
 650
 651            ```python
 652            from prefect import flow, serve
 653
 654            @flow
 655            def my_flow(name):
 656                print(f"hello {name}")
 657
 658            @flow
 659            def my_other_flow(name):
 660                print(f"goodbye {name}")
 661
 662            if __name__ == "__main__":
 663                hello_deploy = my_flow.to_deployment("hello", tags=["dev"])
 664                bye_deploy = my_other_flow.to_deployment("goodbye", tags=["dev"])
 665                serve(hello_deploy, bye_deploy)
 666            ```
 667        """
 668        from prefect.deployments.runner import RunnerDeployment
 669
 670        if not name.endswith(".py"):
 671            raise_on_name_with_banned_characters(name)
 672        if self._storage and self._entrypoint:
 673            return await RunnerDeployment.from_storage(
 674                storage=self._storage,
 675                entrypoint=self._entrypoint,
 676                name=name,
 677                interval=interval,
 678                cron=cron,
 679                rrule=rrule,
 680                paused=paused,
 681                schedules=schedules,
 682                schedule=schedule,
 683                is_schedule_active=is_schedule_active,
 684                tags=tags,
 685                triggers=triggers,
 686                parameters=parameters or {},
 687                description=description,
 688                version=version,
 689                enforce_parameter_schema=enforce_parameter_schema,
 690                work_pool_name=work_pool_name,
 691                work_queue_name=work_queue_name,
 692                job_variables=job_variables,
 693            )
 694        else:
 695            return RunnerDeployment.from_flow(
 696                self,
 697                name=name,
 698                interval=interval,
 699                cron=cron,
 700                rrule=rrule,
 701                paused=paused,
 702                schedules=schedules,
 703                schedule=schedule,
 704                is_schedule_active=is_schedule_active,
 705                tags=tags,
 706                triggers=triggers,
 707                parameters=parameters or {},
 708                description=description,
 709                version=version,
 710                enforce_parameter_schema=enforce_parameter_schema,
 711                work_pool_name=work_pool_name,
 712                work_queue_name=work_queue_name,
 713                job_variables=job_variables,
 714                entrypoint_type=entrypoint_type,
 715            )
 716
 717    @sync_compatible
 718    async def serve(
 719        self,
 720        name: Optional[str] = None,
 721        interval: Optional[
 722            Union[
 723                Iterable[Union[int, float, datetime.timedelta]],
 724                int,
 725                float,
 726                datetime.timedelta,
 727            ]
 728        ] = None,
 729        cron: Optional[Union[Iterable[str], str]] = None,
 730        rrule: Optional[Union[Iterable[str], str]] = None,
 731        paused: Optional[bool] = None,
 732        schedules: Optional[List["FlexibleScheduleList"]] = None,
 733        schedule: Optional[SCHEDULE_TYPES] = None,
 734        is_schedule_active: Optional[bool] = None,
 735        triggers: Optional[List[Union[DeploymentTriggerTypes, TriggerTypes]]] = None,
 736        parameters: Optional[dict] = None,
 737        description: Optional[str] = None,
 738        tags: Optional[List[str]] = None,
 739        version: Optional[str] = None,
 740        enforce_parameter_schema: bool = False,
 741        pause_on_shutdown: bool = True,
 742        print_starting_message: bool = True,
 743        limit: Optional[int] = None,
 744        webserver: bool = False,
 745        entrypoint_type: EntrypointType = EntrypointType.FILE_PATH,
 746    ):
 747        """
 748        Creates a deployment for this flow and starts a runner to monitor for scheduled work.
 749
 750        Args:
 751            name: The name to give the created deployment. Defaults to the name of the flow.
 752            interval: An interval on which to execute the deployment. Accepts a number or a
 753                timedelta object to create a single schedule. If a number is given, it will be
 754                interpreted as seconds. Also accepts an iterable of numbers or timedelta to create
 755                multiple schedules.
 756            cron: A cron schedule string of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 757                Also accepts an iterable of cron schedule strings to create multiple schedules.
 758            rrule: An rrule schedule string of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 759                Also accepts an iterable of rrule schedule strings to create multiple schedules.
 760            triggers: A list of triggers that will kick off runs of this deployment.
 761            paused: Whether or not to set this deployment as paused.
 762            schedules: A list of schedule objects defining when to execute runs of this deployment.
 763                Used to define multiple schedules or additional scheduling options like `timezone`.
 764            schedule: A schedule object defining when to execute runs of this deployment. Used to
 765                define additional scheduling options such as `timezone`.
 766            is_schedule_active: Whether or not to set the schedule for this deployment as active. If
 767                not provided when creating a deployment, the schedule will be set as active. If not
 768                provided when updating a deployment, the schedule's activation will not be changed.
 769            parameters: A dictionary of default parameter values to pass to runs of this deployment.
 770            description: A description for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's
 771                description if not provided.
 772            tags: A list of tags to associate with the created deployment for organizational
 773                purposes.
 774            version: A version for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's version.
 775            enforce_parameter_schema: Whether or not the Prefect API should enforce the
 776                parameter schema for the created deployment.
 777            pause_on_shutdown: If True, provided schedule will be paused when the serve function is stopped.
 778                If False, the schedules will continue running.
 779            print_starting_message: Whether or not to print the starting message when flow is served.
 780            limit: The maximum number of runs that can be executed concurrently.
 781            webserver: Whether or not to start a monitoring webserver for this flow.
 782            entrypoint_type: Type of entrypoint to use for the deployment. When using a module path
 783                entrypoint, ensure that the module will be importable in the execution environment.
 784
 785        Examples:
 786            Serve a flow:
 787
 788            ```python
 789            from prefect import flow
 790
 791            @flow
 792            def my_flow(name):
 793                print(f"hello {name}")
 794
 795            if __name__ == "__main__":
 796                my_flow.serve("example-deployment")
 797            ```
 798
 799            Serve a flow and run it every hour:
 800
 801            ```python
 802            from prefect import flow
 803
 804            @flow
 805            def my_flow(name):
 806                print(f"hello {name}")
 807
 808            if __name__ == "__main__":
 809                my_flow.serve("example-deployment", interval=3600)
 810            ```
 811        """
 812        from prefect.runner import Runner
 813
 814        if not name:
 815            name = self.name
 816        else:
 817            # Handling for my_flow.serve(__file__)
 818            # Will set name to name of file where my_flow.serve() without the extension
 819            # Non filepath strings will pass through unchanged
 820            name = Path(name).stem
 821
 822        runner = Runner(name=name, pause_on_shutdown=pause_on_shutdown, limit=limit)
 823        deployment_id = await runner.add_flow(
 824            self,
 825            name=name,
 826            triggers=triggers,
 827            interval=interval,
 828            cron=cron,
 829            rrule=rrule,
 830            paused=paused,
 831            schedules=schedules,
 832            schedule=schedule,
 833            is_schedule_active=is_schedule_active,
 834            parameters=parameters,
 835            description=description,
 836            tags=tags,
 837            version=version,
 838            enforce_parameter_schema=enforce_parameter_schema,
 839            entrypoint_type=entrypoint_type,
 840        )
 841        if print_starting_message:
 842            help_message = (
 843                f"[green]Your flow {self.name!r} is being served and polling for"
 844                " scheduled runs!\n[/]\nTo trigger a run for this flow, use the"
 845                " following command:\n[blue]\n\t$ prefect deployment run"
 846                f" '{self.name}/{name}'\n[/]"
 847            )
 848            if PREFECT_UI_URL:
 849                help_message += (
 850                    "\nYou can also run your flow via the Prefect UI:"
 851                    f" [blue]{PREFECT_UI_URL.value()}/deployments/deployment/{deployment_id}[/]\n"
 852                )
 853
 854            console = Console()
 855            console.print(help_message, soft_wrap=True)
 856        await runner.start(webserver=webserver)
 857
 858    @classmethod
 859    @sync_compatible
 860    async def from_source(
 861        cls: Type[F],
 862        source: Union[str, RunnerStorage, ReadableDeploymentStorage],
 863        entrypoint: str,
 864    ) -> F:
 865        """
 866        Loads a flow from a remote source.
 867
 868        Args:
 869            source: Either a URL to a git repository or a storage object.
 870            entrypoint:  The path to a file containing a flow and the name of the flow function in
 871                the format `./path/to/file.py:flow_func_name`.
 872
 873        Returns:
 874            A new `Flow` instance.
 875
 876        Examples:
 877            Load a flow from a public git repository:
 878
 879
 880            ```python
 881            from prefect import flow
 882            from prefect.runner.storage import GitRepository
 883            from prefect.blocks.system import Secret
 884
 885            my_flow = flow.from_source(
 886                source="https://github.com/org/repo.git",
 887                entrypoint="flows.py:my_flow",
 888            )
 889
 890            my_flow()
 891            ```
 892
 893            Load a flow from a private git repository using an access token stored in a `Secret` block:
 894
 895            ```python
 896            from prefect import flow
 897            from prefect.runner.storage import GitRepository
 898            from prefect.blocks.system import Secret
 899
 900            my_flow = flow.from_source(
 901                source=GitRepository(
 902                    url="https://github.com/org/repo.git",
 903                    credentials={"access_token": Secret.load("github-access-token")}
 904                ),
 905                entrypoint="flows.py:my_flow",
 906            )
 907
 908            my_flow()
 909            ```
 910        """
 911        if isinstance(source, str):
 912            storage = create_storage_from_url(source)
 913        elif isinstance(source, RunnerStorage):
 914            storage = source
 915        elif hasattr(source, "get_directory"):
 916            storage = BlockStorageAdapter(source)
 917        else:
 918            raise TypeError(
 919                f"Unsupported source type {type(source).__name__!r}. Please provide a"
 920                " URL to remote storage or a storage object."
 921            )
 922        with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmpdir:
 923            storage.set_base_path(Path(tmpdir))
 924            await storage.pull_code()
 925
 926            full_entrypoint = str(storage.destination / entrypoint)
 927            flow: "Flow" = await from_async.wait_for_call_in_new_thread(
 928                create_call(load_flow_from_entrypoint, full_entrypoint)
 929            )
 930            flow._storage = storage
 931            flow._entrypoint = entrypoint
 932
 933        return flow
 934
 935    @sync_compatible
 936    async def deploy(
 937        self,
 938        name: str,
 939        work_pool_name: Optional[str] = None,
 940        image: Optional[Union[str, DeploymentImage]] = None,
 941        build: bool = True,
 942        push: bool = True,
 943        work_queue_name: Optional[str] = None,
 944        job_variables: Optional[dict] = None,
 945        interval: Optional[Union[int, float, datetime.timedelta]] = None,
 946        cron: Optional[str] = None,
 947        rrule: Optional[str] = None,
 948        paused: Optional[bool] = None,
 949        schedules: Optional[List[MinimalDeploymentSchedule]] = None,
 950        schedule: Optional[SCHEDULE_TYPES] = None,
 951        is_schedule_active: Optional[bool] = None,
 952        triggers: Optional[List[Union[DeploymentTriggerTypes, TriggerTypes]]] = None,
 953        parameters: Optional[dict] = None,
 954        description: Optional[str] = None,
 955        tags: Optional[List[str]] = None,
 956        version: Optional[str] = None,
 957        enforce_parameter_schema: bool = False,
 958        entrypoint_type: EntrypointType = EntrypointType.FILE_PATH,
 959        print_next_steps: bool = True,
 960        ignore_warnings: bool = False,
 961    ) -> UUID:
 962        """
 963        Deploys a flow to run on dynamic infrastructure via a work pool.
 964
 965        By default, calling this method will build a Docker image for the flow, push it to a registry,
 966        and create a deployment via the Prefect API that will run the flow on the given schedule.
 967
 968        If you want to use an existing image, you can pass `build=False` to skip building and pushing
 969        an image.
 970
 971        Args:
 972            name: The name to give the created deployment.
 973            work_pool_name: The name of the work pool to use for this deployment. Defaults to
 974                the value of `PREFECT_DEFAULT_WORK_POOL_NAME`.
 975            image: The name of the Docker image to build, including the registry and
 976                repository. Pass a DeploymentImage instance to customize the Dockerfile used
 977                and build arguments.
 978            build: Whether or not to build a new image for the flow. If False, the provided
 979                image will be used as-is and pulled at runtime.
 980            push: Whether or not to skip pushing the built image to a registry.
 981            work_queue_name: The name of the work queue to use for this deployment's scheduled runs.
 982                If not provided the default work queue for the work pool will be used.
 983            job_variables: Settings used to override the values specified default base job template
 984                of the chosen work pool. Refer to the base job template of the chosen work pool for
 985                available settings.
 986            interval: An interval on which to execute the deployment. Accepts a number or a
 987                timedelta object to create a single schedule. If a number is given, it will be
 988                interpreted as seconds. Also accepts an iterable of numbers or timedelta to create
 989                multiple schedules.
 990            cron: A cron schedule string of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 991                Also accepts an iterable of cron schedule strings to create multiple schedules.
 992            rrule: An rrule schedule string of when to execute runs of this deployment.
 993                Also accepts an iterable of rrule schedule strings to create multiple schedules.
 994            triggers: A list of triggers that will kick off runs of this deployment.
 995            paused: Whether or not to set this deployment as paused.
 996            schedules: A list of schedule objects defining when to execute runs of this deployment.
 997                Used to define multiple schedules or additional scheduling options like `timezone`.
 998            schedule: A schedule object defining when to execute runs of this deployment. Used to
 999                define additional scheduling options like `timezone`.
1000            is_schedule_active: Whether or not to set the schedule for this deployment as active. If
1001                not provided when creating a deployment, the schedule will be set as active. If not
1002                provided when updating a deployment, the schedule's activation will not be changed.
1003            parameters: A dictionary of default parameter values to pass to runs of this deployment.
1004            description: A description for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's
1005                description if not provided.
1006            tags: A list of tags to associate with the created deployment for organizational
1007                purposes.
1008            version: A version for the created deployment. Defaults to the flow's version.
1009            enforce_parameter_schema: Whether or not the Prefect API should enforce the
1010                parameter schema for the created deployment.
1011            entrypoint_type: Type of entrypoint to use for the deployment. When using a module path
1012                entrypoint, ensure that the module will be importable in the execution environment.
1013            print_next_steps_message: Whether or not to print a message with next steps
1014                after deploying the deployments.
1015            ignore_warnings: Whether or not to ignore warnings about the work pool type.
1016
1017        Returns:
1018            The ID of the created/updated deployment.
1019
1020        Examples:
1021            Deploy a local flow to a work pool:
1022
1023            ```python
1024            from prefect import flow
1025
1026            @flow
1027            def my_flow(name):
1028                print(f"hello {name}")
1029
1030            if __name__ == "__main__":
1031                my_flow.deploy(
1032                    "example-deployment",
1033                    work_pool_name="my-work-pool",
1034                    image="my-repository/my-image:dev",
1035                )
1036            ```
1037
1038            Deploy a remotely stored flow to a work pool:
1039
1040            ```python
1041            from prefect import flow
1042
1043            if __name__ == "__main__":
1044                flow.from_source(
1045                    source="https://github.com/org/repo.git",
1046                    entrypoint="flows.py:my_flow",
1047                ).deploy(
1048                    "example-deployment",
1049                    work_pool_name="my-work-pool",
1050                    image="my-repository/my-image:dev",
1051                )
1052            ```
1053        """
1054        work_pool_name = work_pool_name or PREFECT_DEFAULT_WORK_POOL_NAME.value()
1055
1056        try:
1057            async with get_client() as client:
1058                work_pool = await client.read_work_pool(work_pool_name)
1059        except ObjectNotFound as exc:
1060            raise ValueError(
1061                f"Could not find work pool {work_pool_name!r}. Please create it before"
1062                " deploying this flow."
1063            ) from exc
1064
1065        deployment = await self.to_deployment(
1066            name=name,
1067            interval=interval,
1068            cron=cron,
1069            rrule=rrule,
1070            schedules=schedules,
1071            paused=paused,
1072            schedule=schedule,
1073            is_schedule_active=is_schedule_active,
1074            triggers=triggers,
1075            parameters=parameters,
1076            description=description,
1077            tags=tags,
1078            version=version,
1079            enforce_parameter_schema=enforce_parameter_schema,
1080            work_queue_name=work_queue_name,
1081            job_variables=job_variables,
1082            entrypoint_type=entrypoint_type,
1083        )
1084
1085        deployment_ids = await deploy(
1086            deployment,
1087            work_pool_name=work_pool_name,
1088            image=image,
1089            build=build,
1090            push=push,
1091            print_next_steps_message=False,
1092            ignore_warnings=ignore_warnings,
1093        )
1094
1095        if print_next_steps:
1096            console = Console()
1097            if not work_pool.is_push_pool and not work_pool.is_managed_pool:
1098                console.print(
1099                    "\nTo execute flow runs from this deployment, start a worker in a"
1100                    " separate terminal that pulls work from the"
1101                    f" {work_pool_name!r} work pool:"
1102                )
1103                console.print(
1104                    f"\n\t$ prefect worker start --pool {work_pool_name!r}",
1105                    style="blue",
1106                )
1107            console.print(
1108                "\nTo schedule a run for this deployment, use the following command:"
1109            )
1110            console.print(
1111                f"\n\t$ prefect deployment run '{self.name}/{name}'\n",
1112                style="blue",
1113            )
1114            if PREFECT_UI_URL:
1115                message = (
1116                    "\nYou can also run your flow via the Prefect UI:"
1117                    f" [blue]{PREFECT_UI_URL.value()}/deployments/deployment/{deployment_ids[0]}[/]\n"
1118                )
1119                console.print(message, soft_wrap=True)
1120
1121        return deployment_ids[0]
1122

1143    @overload
1144    def __call__(
1145        self: "Flow[P, T]",
1146        *args: P.args,
1147        return_state: Literal[True],
1148        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
1149    ) -> State[T]:
1150        ...
1151
1152    def __call__(
1153        self,
1154        *args: "P.args",
1155        return_state: bool = False,
1156        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
1157        **kwargs: "P.kwargs",
1158    ):
1159        """
1160        Run the flow and return its result.
1161
1162
1163        Flow parameter values must be serializable by Pydantic.
1164
1165        If writing an async flow, this call must be awaited.
1166
1167        This will create a new flow run in the API.
1168
1169        Args:
1170            *args: Arguments to run the flow with.
1171            return_state: Return a Prefect State containing the result of the
1172                flow run.
1173            wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the flow if called as a subflow
1174            **kwargs: Keyword arguments to run the flow with.
1175
1176        Returns:
1177            If `return_state` is False, returns the result of the flow run.
1178            If `return_state` is True, returns the result of the flow run
1179                wrapped in a Prefect State which provides error handling.
1180
1181        Examples:
1182
1183            Define a flow
1184
1185            >>> @flow
1186            >>> def my_flow(name):
1187            >>>     print(f"hello {name}")
1188            >>>     return f"goodbye {name}"
1189
1190            Run a flow
1191
1192            >>> my_flow("marvin")
1193            hello marvin
1194            "goodbye marvin"
1195
1196            Run a flow with additional tags
1197
1198            >>> from prefect import tags
1199            >>> with tags("db", "blue"):
1200            >>>     my_flow("foo")
1201        """
1202        from prefect.engine import enter_flow_run_engine_from_flow_call
1203
1204        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
1205        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
1206
1207        return_type = "state" if return_state else "result"
1208
1209        task_viz_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
1210        if task_viz_tracker:
1211            # this is a subflow, for now return a single task and do not go further
1212            # we can add support for exploring subflows for tasks in the future.
1213            return track_viz_task(self.isasync, self.name, parameters)
1214
1215        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_NEW_ENGINE.value():
1216            from prefect.new_flow_engine import run_flow, run_flow_sync
1217
1218            run_kwargs = dict(
1219                flow=self,
1220                parameters=parameters,
1221                wait_for=wait_for,
1222                return_type=return_type,
1223            )
1224            if self.isasync:
1225                # this returns an awaitable coroutine
1226                return run_flow(**run_kwargs)
1227            else:
1228                return run_flow_sync(**run_kwargs)
1229
1230        return enter_flow_run_engine_from_flow_call(
1231            self,
1232            parameters,
1233            wait_for=wait_for,
1234            return_type=return_type,
1235        )
1236
1237    @overload
1238    def _run(self: "Flow[P, NoReturn]", *args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> State[T]:
1239        # `NoReturn` matches if a type can't be inferred for the function which stops a
1240        # sync function from matching the `Coroutine` overload
1241        ...
1242
1243    @overload
1244    def _run(

1246    ) -> Awaitable[T]:
1247        ...

1249    @overload
1250    def _run(self: "Flow[P, T]", *args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> State[T]:
1251        ...
1252
1253    def _run(
1254        self,
1255        *args: "P.args",
1256        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
1257        **kwargs: "P.kwargs",
1258    ):
1259        """
1260        Run the flow and return its final state.
1261
1262        Examples:
1263
1264            Run a flow and get the returned result
1265
1266            >>> state = my_flow._run("marvin")
1267            >>> state.result()
1268           "goodbye marvin"
1269        """
1270        from prefect.engine import enter_flow_run_engine_from_flow_call
1271
1272        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
1273        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
1274
1275        return enter_flow_run_engine_from_flow_call(
1276            self,
1277            parameters,
1278            wait_for=wait_for,
1279            return_type="state",
1280        )
