@contextmanager
def tags(*new_tags: str) -> Generator[Set[str], NoneType, NoneType]: 
399@contextmanager
400def tags(*new_tags: str) -> Generator[Set[str], None, None]:
401    """
402    Context manager to add tags to flow and task run calls.
403
404    Tags are always combined with any existing tags.
405
406    Yields:
407        The current set of tags
408
409    Examples:
410        >>> from prefect import tags, task, flow
411        >>> @task
412        >>> def my_task():
413        >>>     pass
414
415        Run a task with tags
416
417        >>> @flow
418        >>> def my_flow():
419        >>>     with tags("a", "b"):
420        >>>         my_task()  # has tags: a, b
421
422        Run a flow with tags
423
424        >>> @flow
425        >>> def my_flow():
426        >>>     pass
427        >>> with tags("a", "b"):
428        >>>     my_flow()  # has tags: a, b
429
430        Run a task with nested tag contexts
431
432        >>> @flow
433        >>> def my_flow():
434        >>>     with tags("a", "b"):
435        >>>         with tags("c", "d"):
436        >>>             my_task()  # has tags: a, b, c, d
437        >>>         my_task()  # has tags: a, b
438
439        Inspect the current tags
440
441        >>> @flow
442        >>> def my_flow():
443        >>>     with tags("c", "d"):
444        >>>         with tags("e", "f") as current_tags:
445        >>>              print(current_tags)
446        >>> with tags("a", "b"):
447        >>>     my_flow()
448        {"a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"}
449    """
450    current_tags = TagsContext.get().current_tags
451    new_tags = current_tags.union(new_tags)
452    with TagsContext(current_tags=new_tags):
453        yield new_tags

1269        int,

1271        Callable[[int], List[float]],

1273    retry_jitter_factor: Optional[float] = None,
1274    persist_result: Optional[bool] = None,
1275    result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = None,

1277    result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = None,
1278    cache_result_in_memory: bool = True,

1284    retry_condition_fn: Optional[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], bool]] = None,
1285    viz_return_value: Any = None,
1286):
1287    """
1288    Decorator to designate a function as a task in a Prefect workflow.
1289
1290    This decorator may be used for asynchronous or synchronous functions.
1291
1292    Args:
1293        name: An optional name for the task; if not provided, the name will be inferred
1294            from the given function.
1295        description: An optional string description for the task.
1296        tags: An optional set of tags to be associated with runs of this task. These
1297            tags are combined with any tags defined by a `prefect.tags` context at
1298            task runtime.
1299        version: An optional string specifying the version of this task definition
1300        cache_key_fn: An optional callable that, given the task run context and call
1301            parameters, generates a string key; if the key matches a previous completed
1302            state, that state result will be restored instead of running the task again.
1303        cache_expiration: An optional amount of time indicating how long cached states
1304            for this task should be restorable; if not provided, cached states will
1305            never expire.
1306        task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided
1307            as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables,
1308            or a function that returns a string.
1309        retries: An optional number of times to retry on task run failure
1310        retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying the
1311            task after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero. This
1312            setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays, or a
1313            callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list of retry
1314            delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to all retries.
1315            If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay before retrying.
1316            When passing a callable or a list, the number of configured retry delays
1317            cannot exceed 50.
1318        retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a retry
1319            can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd".
1320        persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this task
1321            should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
1322            that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on
1323            the features being used.
1324        result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this task.
1325            Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is called in.
1326        result_storage_key: An optional key to store the result in storage at when persisted.
1327            Defaults to a unique identifier.
1328        result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this
1329            task for persistence. Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is
1330            called in.
1331        timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for
1332            the task. If the task exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed.
1333        log_prints: If set, `print` statements in the task will be redirected to the
1334            Prefect logger for the task run. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
1335            that the value from the flow should be used.
1336        refresh_cache: If set, cached results for the cache key are not used.
1337            Defaults to `None`, which indicates that a cached result from a previous
1338            execution with matching cache key is used.
1339        on_failure: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state.
1340        on_completion: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state.
1341        retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state. Should
1342            return `True` if the task should continue to its retry policy (e.g. `retries=3`), and `False` if the task
1343            should end as failed. Defaults to `None`, indicating the task should always continue
1344            to its retry policy.
1345        viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.
1346
1347    Returns:
1348        A callable `Task` object which, when called, will submit the task for execution.
1349
1350    Examples:
1351        Define a simple task
1352
1353        >>> @task
1354        >>> def add(x, y):
1355        >>>     return x + y
1356
1357        Define an async task
1358
1359        >>> @task
1360        >>> async def add(x, y):
1361        >>>     return x + y
1362
1363        Define a task with tags and a description
1364
1365        >>> @task(tags={"a", "b"}, description="This task is empty but its my first!")
1366        >>> def my_task():
1367        >>>     pass
1368
1369        Define a task with a custom name
1370
1371        >>> @task(name="The Ultimate Task")
1372        >>> def my_task():
1373        >>>     pass
1374
1375        Define a task that retries 3 times with a 5 second delay between attempts
1376
1377        >>> from random import randint
1378        >>>
1379        >>> @task(retries=3, retry_delay_seconds=5)
1380        >>> def my_task():
1381        >>>     x = randint(0, 5)
1382        >>>     if x >= 3:  # Make a task that fails sometimes
1383        >>>         raise ValueError("Retry me please!")
1384        >>>     return x
1385
1386        Define a task that is cached for a day based on its inputs
1387
1388        >>> from prefect.tasks import task_input_hash
1389        >>> from datetime import timedelta
1390        >>>
1391        >>> @task(cache_key_fn=task_input_hash, cache_expiration=timedelta(days=1))
1392        >>> def my_task():
1393        >>>     return "hello"

@PrefectObjectRegistry.register_instances
class Task(typing.Generic[~P, ~R]): 
 129@PrefectObjectRegistry.register_instances
 130class Task(Generic[P, R]):
 131    """
 132    A Prefect task definition.
 133
 134    !!! note
 135        We recommend using [the `@task` decorator][prefect.tasks.task] for most use-cases.
 136
 137    Wraps a function with an entrypoint to the Prefect engine. Calling this class within a flow function
 138    creates a new task run.
 139
 140    To preserve the input and output types, we use the generic type variables P and R for "Parameters" and
 141    "Returns" respectively.
 142
 143    Args:
 144        fn: The function defining the task.
 145        name: An optional name for the task; if not provided, the name will be inferred
 146            from the given function.
 147        description: An optional string description for the task.
 148        tags: An optional set of tags to be associated with runs of this task. These
 149            tags are combined with any tags defined by a `prefect.tags` context at
 150            task runtime.
 151        version: An optional string specifying the version of this task definition
 152        cache_key_fn: An optional callable that, given the task run context and call
 153            parameters, generates a string key; if the key matches a previous completed
 154            state, that state result will be restored instead of running the task again.
 155        cache_expiration: An optional amount of time indicating how long cached states
 156            for this task should be restorable; if not provided, cached states will
 157            never expire.
 158        task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided
 159            as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables,
 160            or a function that returns a string.
 161        retries: An optional number of times to retry on task run failure.
 162        retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying the
 163            task after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero. This
 164            setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays, or a
 165            callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list of retry
 166            delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to all retries.
 167            If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay before retrying.
 168            When passing a callable or a list, the number of configured retry delays
 169            cannot exceed 50.
 170        retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a retry
 171            can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd".
 172        persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this task
 173            should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
 174            that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on
 175            the features being used.
 176        result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this task.
 177            Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is called in.
 178        result_storage_key: An optional key to store the result in storage at when persisted.
 179            Defaults to a unique identifier.
 180        result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this
 181            task for persistence. Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is
 182            called in.
 183        timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for
 184            the task. If the task exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed.
 185        log_prints: If set, `print` statements in the task will be redirected to the
 186            Prefect logger for the task run. Defaults to `None`, which indicates
 187            that the value from the flow should be used.
 188        refresh_cache: If set, cached results for the cache key are not used.
 189            Defaults to `None`, which indicates that a cached result from a previous
 190            execution with matching cache key is used.
 191        on_failure: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state.
 192        on_completion: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state.
 193        retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state. Should
 194            return `True` if the task should continue to its retry policy (e.g. `retries=3`), and `False` if the task
 195            should end as failed. Defaults to `None`, indicating the task should always continue
 196            to its retry policy.
 197        viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.
 198    """
 199
 200    # NOTE: These parameters (types, defaults, and docstrings) should be duplicated
 201    #       exactly in the @task decorator
 202    def __init__(
 203        self,
 204        fn: Callable[P, R],
 205        name: Optional[str] = None,
 206        description: Optional[str] = None,
 207        tags: Optional[Iterable[str]] = None,
 208        version: Optional[str] = None,
 209        cache_key_fn: Optional[
 210            Callable[["TaskRunContext", Dict[str, Any]], Optional[str]]
 211        ] = None,
 212        cache_expiration: Optional[datetime.timedelta] = None,
 213        task_run_name: Optional[Union[Callable[[], str], str]] = None,
 214        retries: Optional[int] = None,
 215        retry_delay_seconds: Optional[
 216            Union[
 217                float,
 218                int,
 219                List[float],
 220                Callable[[int], List[float]],
 221            ]
 222        ] = None,
 223        retry_jitter_factor: Optional[float] = None,
 224        persist_result: Optional[bool] = None,
 225        result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = None,
 226        result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = None,
 227        result_storage_key: Optional[str] = None,
 228        cache_result_in_memory: bool = True,
 229        timeout_seconds: Union[int, float, None] = None,
 230        log_prints: Optional[bool] = False,
 231        refresh_cache: Optional[bool] = None,
 232        on_completion: Optional[List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], None]]] = None,
 233        on_failure: Optional[List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], None]]] = None,
 234        retry_condition_fn: Optional[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], bool]] = None,
 235        viz_return_value: Optional[Any] = None,
 236    ):
 237        # Validate if hook passed is list and contains callables
 238        hook_categories = [on_completion, on_failure]
 239        hook_names = ["on_completion", "on_failure"]
 240        for hooks, hook_name in zip(hook_categories, hook_names):
 241            if hooks is not None:
 242                if not hooks:
 243                    raise ValueError(f"Empty list passed for '{hook_name}'")
 244                try:
 245                    hooks = list(hooks)
 246                except TypeError:
 247                    raise TypeError(
 248                        f"Expected iterable for '{hook_name}'; got"
 249                        f" {type(hooks).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
 250                        f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
 251                        f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
 252                        " my_flow():\n\tpass"
 253                    )
 254
 255                for hook in hooks:
 256                    if not callable(hook):
 257                        raise TypeError(
 258                            f"Expected callables in '{hook_name}'; got"
 259                            f" {type(hook).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
 260                            f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
 261                            f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
 262                            " my_flow():\n\tpass"
 263                        )
 264
 265        if not callable(fn):
 266            raise TypeError("'fn' must be callable")
 267
 268        self.description = description or inspect.getdoc(fn)
 269        update_wrapper(self, fn)
 270        self.fn = fn
 271        self.isasync = inspect.iscoroutinefunction(self.fn)
 272
 273        if not name:
 274            if not hasattr(self.fn, "__name__"):
 275                self.name = type(self.fn).__name__
 276            else:
 277                self.name = self.fn.__name__
 278        else:
 279            self.name = name
 280
 281        if task_run_name is not None:
 282            if not isinstance(task_run_name, str) and not callable(task_run_name):
 283                raise TypeError(
 284                    "Expected string or callable for 'task_run_name'; got"
 285                    f" {type(task_run_name).__name__} instead."
 286                )
 287        self.task_run_name = task_run_name
 288
 289        self.version = version
 290        self.log_prints = log_prints
 291
 292        raise_for_reserved_arguments(self.fn, ["return_state", "wait_for"])
 293
 294        self.tags = set(tags if tags else [])
 295
 296        if not hasattr(self.fn, "__qualname__"):
 297            self.task_key = to_qualified_name(type(self.fn))
 298        else:
 299            try:
 300                task_origin_hash = hash_objects(
 301                    self.name, os.path.abspath(inspect.getsourcefile(self.fn))
 302                )
 303            except TypeError:
 304                task_origin_hash = "unknown-source-file"
 305
 306            self.task_key = f"{self.fn.__qualname__}-{task_origin_hash}"
 307
 308        self.cache_key_fn = cache_key_fn
 309        self.cache_expiration = cache_expiration
 310        self.refresh_cache = refresh_cache
 311
 312        # TaskRunPolicy settings
 313        # TODO: We can instantiate a `TaskRunPolicy` and add Pydantic bound checks to
 314        #       validate that the user passes positive numbers here
 315
 316        self.retries = (
 317            retries if retries is not None else PREFECT_TASK_DEFAULT_RETRIES.value()
 318        )
 319        if retry_delay_seconds is None:
 320            retry_delay_seconds = PREFECT_TASK_DEFAULT_RETRY_DELAY_SECONDS.value()
 321
 322        if callable(retry_delay_seconds):
 323            self.retry_delay_seconds = retry_delay_seconds(retries)
 324        else:
 325            self.retry_delay_seconds = retry_delay_seconds
 326
 327        if isinstance(self.retry_delay_seconds, list) and (
 328            len(self.retry_delay_seconds) > 50
 329        ):
 330            raise ValueError("Can not configure more than 50 retry delays per task.")
 331
 332        if retry_jitter_factor is not None and retry_jitter_factor < 0:
 333            raise ValueError("`retry_jitter_factor` must be >= 0.")
 334
 335        self.retry_jitter_factor = retry_jitter_factor
 336        self.persist_result = persist_result
 337        self.result_storage = result_storage
 338        self.result_serializer = result_serializer
 339        self.result_storage_key = result_storage_key
 340        self.cache_result_in_memory = cache_result_in_memory
 341        self.timeout_seconds = float(timeout_seconds) if timeout_seconds else None
 342        self.on_completion = on_completion
 343        self.on_failure = on_failure
 344
 345        # retry_condition_fn must be a callable or None. If it is neither, raise a TypeError
 346        if retry_condition_fn is not None and not (callable(retry_condition_fn)):
 347            raise TypeError(
 348                "Expected `retry_condition_fn` to be callable, got"
 349                f" {type(retry_condition_fn).__name__} instead."
 350            )
 351
 352        self.retry_condition_fn = retry_condition_fn
 353        self.viz_return_value = viz_return_value
 354
 355    def with_options(
 356        self,
 357        *,
 358        name: str = None,
 359        description: str = None,
 360        tags: Iterable[str] = None,
 361        cache_key_fn: Callable[
 362            ["TaskRunContext", Dict[str, Any]], Optional[str]
 363        ] = None,
 364        task_run_name: Optional[Union[Callable[[], str], str]] = None,
 365        cache_expiration: datetime.timedelta = None,
 366        retries: Optional[int] = NotSet,
 367        retry_delay_seconds: Union[
 368            float,
 369            int,
 370            List[float],
 371            Callable[[int], List[float]],
 372        ] = NotSet,
 373        retry_jitter_factor: Optional[float] = NotSet,
 374        persist_result: Optional[bool] = NotSet,
 375        result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = NotSet,
 376        result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = NotSet,
 377        result_storage_key: Optional[str] = NotSet,
 378        cache_result_in_memory: Optional[bool] = None,
 379        timeout_seconds: Union[int, float] = None,
 380        log_prints: Optional[bool] = NotSet,
 381        refresh_cache: Optional[bool] = NotSet,
 382        on_completion: Optional[
 383            List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], Union[Awaitable[None], None]]]
 384        ] = None,
 385        on_failure: Optional[
 386            List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], Union[Awaitable[None], None]]]
 387        ] = None,
 388        retry_condition_fn: Optional[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], bool]] = None,
 389        viz_return_value: Optional[Any] = None,
 390    ):
 391        """
 392        Create a new task from the current object, updating provided options.
 393
 394        Args:
 395            name: A new name for the task.
 396            description: A new description for the task.
 397            tags: A new set of tags for the task. If given, existing tags are ignored,
 398                not merged.
 399            cache_key_fn: A new cache key function for the task.
 400            cache_expiration: A new cache expiration time for the task.
 401            task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided
 402                as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables,
 403                or a function that returns a string.
 404            retries: A new number of times to retry on task run failure.
 405            retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying
 406                the task after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero.
 407                This setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays,
 408                or a callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list
 409                of retry delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to
 410                all retries. If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay
 411                before retrying. When passing a callable or a list, the number of
 412                configured retry delays cannot exceed 50.
 413            retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a
 414                retry can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd".
 415            persist_result: A new option for enabling or disabling result persistence.
 416            result_storage: A new storage type to use for results.
 417            result_serializer: A new serializer to use for results.
 418            result_storage_key: A new key for the persisted result to be stored at.
 419            timeout_seconds: A new maximum time for the task to complete in seconds.
 420            log_prints: A new option for enabling or disabling redirection of `print` statements.
 421            refresh_cache: A new option for enabling or disabling cache refresh.
 422            on_completion: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state.
 423            on_failure: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state.
 424            retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state.
 425                Should return `True` if the task should continue to its retry policy, and `False`
 426                if the task should end as failed. Defaults to `None`, indicating the task should
 427                always continue to its retry policy.
 428            viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.
 429
 430        Returns:
 431            A new `Task` instance.
 432
 433        Examples:
 434
 435            Create a new task from an existing task and update the name
 436
 437            >>> @task(name="My task")
 438            >>> def my_task():
 439            >>>     return 1
 440            >>>
 441            >>> new_task = my_task.with_options(name="My new task")
 442
 443            Create a new task from an existing task and update the retry settings
 444
 445            >>> from random import randint
 446            >>>
 447            >>> @task(retries=1, retry_delay_seconds=5)
 448            >>> def my_task():
 449            >>>     x = randint(0, 5)
 450            >>>     if x >= 3:  # Make a task that fails sometimes
 451            >>>         raise ValueError("Retry me please!")
 452            >>>     return x
 453            >>>
 454            >>> new_task = my_task.with_options(retries=5, retry_delay_seconds=2)
 455
 456            Use a task with updated options within a flow
 457
 458            >>> @task(name="My task")
 459            >>> def my_task():
 460            >>>     return 1
 461            >>>
 462            >>> @flow
 463            >>> my_flow():
 464            >>>     new_task = my_task.with_options(name="My new task")
 465            >>>     new_task()
 466        """
 467        return Task(
 468            fn=self.fn,
 469            name=name or self.name,
 470            description=description or self.description,
 471            tags=tags or copy(self.tags),
 472            cache_key_fn=cache_key_fn or self.cache_key_fn,
 473            cache_expiration=cache_expiration or self.cache_expiration,
 474            task_run_name=task_run_name,
 475            retries=retries if retries is not NotSet else self.retries,
 476            retry_delay_seconds=(
 477                retry_delay_seconds
 478                if retry_delay_seconds is not NotSet
 479                else self.retry_delay_seconds
 480            ),
 481            retry_jitter_factor=(
 482                retry_jitter_factor
 483                if retry_jitter_factor is not NotSet
 484                else self.retry_jitter_factor
 485            ),
 486            persist_result=(
 487                persist_result if persist_result is not NotSet else self.persist_result
 488            ),
 489            result_storage=(
 490                result_storage if result_storage is not NotSet else self.result_storage
 491            ),
 492            result_storage_key=(
 493                result_storage_key
 494                if result_storage_key is not NotSet
 495                else self.result_storage_key
 496            ),
 497            result_serializer=(
 498                result_serializer
 499                if result_serializer is not NotSet
 500                else self.result_serializer
 501            ),
 502            cache_result_in_memory=(
 503                cache_result_in_memory
 504                if cache_result_in_memory is not None
 505                else self.cache_result_in_memory
 506            ),
 507            timeout_seconds=(
 508                timeout_seconds if timeout_seconds is not None else self.timeout_seconds
 509            ),
 510            log_prints=(log_prints if log_prints is not NotSet else self.log_prints),
 511            refresh_cache=(
 512                refresh_cache if refresh_cache is not NotSet else self.refresh_cache
 513            ),
 514            on_completion=on_completion or self.on_completion,
 515            on_failure=on_failure or self.on_failure,
 516            retry_condition_fn=retry_condition_fn or self.retry_condition_fn,
 517            viz_return_value=viz_return_value or self.viz_return_value,
 518        )
 519
 520    async def create_run(
 521        self,
 522        client: Optional[Union[PrefectClient, SyncPrefectClient]],
 523        parameters: Dict[str, Any] = None,
 524        flow_run_context: Optional[FlowRunContext] = None,
 525        parent_task_run_context: Optional[TaskRunContext] = None,
 526        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
 527        extra_task_inputs: Optional[Dict[str, Set[TaskRunInput]]] = None,
 528    ) -> TaskRun:
 529        from prefect.utilities.engine import (
 530            _dynamic_key_for_task_run,
 531            _resolve_custom_task_run_name,
 532            collect_task_run_inputs,
 533        )
 534
 535        if flow_run_context is None:
 536            flow_run_context = FlowRunContext.get()
 537        if parent_task_run_context is None:
 538            parent_task_run_context = TaskRunContext.get()
 539        if parameters is None:
 540            parameters = {}
 541
 542        try:
 543            task_run_name = _resolve_custom_task_run_name(self, parameters)
 544        except TypeError:
 545            task_run_name = None
 546
 547        if flow_run_context:
 548            dynamic_key = _dynamic_key_for_task_run(context=flow_run_context, task=self)
 549        else:
 550            dynamic_key = uuid4().hex
 551
 552        # collect task inputs
 553        task_inputs = {
 554            k: await collect_task_run_inputs(v) for k, v in parameters.items()
 555        }
 556
 557        # check if this task has a parent task run based on running in another
 558        # task run's existing context. A task run is only considered a parent if
 559        # it is in the same flow run (because otherwise presumably the child is
 560        # in a subflow, so the subflow serves as the parent) or if there is no
 561        # flow run
 562        if parent_task_run_context:
 563            # there is no flow run
 564            if not flow_run_context:
 565                task_inputs["__parents__"] = [
 566                    TaskRunResult(id=parent_task_run_context.task_run.id)
 567                ]
 568            # there is a flow run and the task run is in the same flow run
 569            elif (
 570                flow_run_context
 571                and parent_task_run_context.task_run.flow_run_id
 572                == flow_run_context.flow_run.id
 573            ):
 574                task_inputs["__parents__"] = [
 575                    TaskRunResult(id=parent_task_run_context.task_run.id)
 576                ]
 577
 578        if wait_for:
 579            task_inputs["wait_for"] = await collect_task_run_inputs(wait_for)
 580
 581        # Join extra task inputs
 582        for k, extras in (extra_task_inputs or {}).items():
 583            task_inputs[k] = task_inputs[k].union(extras)
 584
 585        # create the task run
 586        task_run = client.create_task_run(
 587            task=self,
 588            name=task_run_name,
 589            flow_run_id=(
 590                getattr(flow_run_context.flow_run, "id", None)
 591                if flow_run_context and flow_run_context.flow_run
 592                else None
 593            ),
 594            dynamic_key=str(dynamic_key),
 595            state=Pending(),
 596            task_inputs=task_inputs,
 597            extra_tags=TagsContext.get().current_tags,
 598        )
 599        # the new engine uses sync clients but old engines use async clients
 600        if inspect.isawaitable(task_run):
 601            task_run = await task_run
 602
 603        if flow_run_context and flow_run_context.flow_run:
 604            get_run_logger(flow_run_context).debug(
 605                f"Created task run {task_run.name!r} for task {self.name!r}"
 606            )
 607        else:
 608            logger.debug(f"Created task run {task_run.name!r} for task {self.name!r}")
 609
 610        return task_run
 611
 612    @overload
 613    def __call__(
 614        self: "Task[P, NoReturn]",
 615        *args: P.args,
 616        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 617    ) -> None:
 618        # `NoReturn` matches if a type can't be inferred for the function which stops a
 619        # sync function from matching the `Coroutine` overload
 620        ...
 621
 622    @overload
 623    def __call__(
 624        self: "Task[P, T]",
 625        *args: P.args,
 626        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 627    ) -> T:
 628        ...
 629
 630    @overload
 631    def __call__(
 632        self: "Task[P, T]",
 633        *args: P.args,
 634        return_state: Literal[True],
 635        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 636    ) -> State[T]:
 637        ...
 638
 639    def __call__(
 640        self,
 641        *args: P.args,
 642        return_state: bool = False,
 643        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
 644        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 645    ):
 646        """
 647        Run the task and return the result. If `return_state` is True returns
 648        the result is wrapped in a Prefect State which provides error handling.
 649        """
 650        from prefect.engine import enter_task_run_engine
 651        from prefect.task_engine import submit_autonomous_task_run_to_engine
 652        from prefect.task_runners import SequentialTaskRunner
 653
 654        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
 655        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
 656
 657        return_type = "state" if return_state else "result"
 658
 659        task_run_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
 660        if task_run_tracker:
 661            return track_viz_task(
 662                self.isasync, self.name, parameters, self.viz_return_value
 663            )
 664
 665        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_NEW_ENGINE.value():
 666            from prefect.new_task_engine import run_task
 667
 668            return run_task(
 669                task=self,
 670                parameters=parameters,
 671                wait_for=wait_for,
 672                return_type=return_type,
 673            )
 674
 675        if (
 676            PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING.value()
 677            and not FlowRunContext.get()
 678        ):
 679            from prefect import get_client
 680
 681            return submit_autonomous_task_run_to_engine(
 682                task=self,
 683                task_run=None,
 684                task_runner=SequentialTaskRunner(),
 685                parameters=parameters,
 686                return_type=return_type,
 687                client=get_client(),
 688            )
 689
 690        return enter_task_run_engine(
 691            self,
 692            parameters=parameters,
 693            wait_for=wait_for,
 694            task_runner=SequentialTaskRunner(),
 695            return_type=return_type,
 696            mapped=False,
 697        )
 698

 703        **kwargs: P.kwargs,

 706        # sync function from matching the `Coroutine` overload

 725    def _run(
 726        self,
 727        *args: P.args,
 728        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
 729        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 730    ) -> Union[State, Awaitable[State]]:
 731        """
 732        Run the task and return the final state.
 733        """
 734        from prefect.engine import enter_task_run_engine
 735        from prefect.task_runners import SequentialTaskRunner
 736
 737        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
 738        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
 739
 740        return enter_task_run_engine(
 741            self,
 742            parameters=parameters,
 743            wait_for=wait_for,
 744            return_type="state",
 745            task_runner=SequentialTaskRunner(),
 746            mapped=False,
 747        )

 800    def submit(
 801        self,
 802        *args: Any,
 803        return_state: bool = False,
 804        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
 805        **kwargs: Any,
 806    ) -> Union[PrefectFuture, Awaitable[PrefectFuture], TaskRun, Awaitable[TaskRun]]:
 807        """
 808        Submit a run of the task to the engine.
 809
 810        If writing an async task, this call must be awaited.
 811
 812        If called from within a flow function,
 813
 814        Will create a new task run in the backing API and submit the task to the flow's
 815        task runner. This call only blocks execution while the task is being submitted,
 816        once it is submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note
 817        that the `SequentialTaskRunner` does not implement parallel execution for sync tasks
 818        and they are fully resolved on submission.
 819
 820        Args:
 821            *args: Arguments to run the task with
 822            return_state: Return the result of the flow run wrapped in a
 823                Prefect State.
 824            wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the task
 825            **kwargs: Keyword arguments to run the task with
 826
 827        Returns:
 828            If `return_state` is False a future allowing asynchronous access to
 829                the state of the task
 830            If `return_state` is True a future wrapped in a Prefect State allowing asynchronous access to
 831                the state of the task
 832
 833        Examples:
 834
 835            Define a task
 836
 837            >>> from prefect import task
 838            >>> @task
 839            >>> def my_task():
 840            >>>     return "hello"
 841
 842            Run a task in a flow
 843
 844            >>> from prefect import flow
 845            >>> @flow
 846            >>> def my_flow():
 847            >>>     my_task.submit()
 848
 849            Wait for a task to finish
 850
 851            >>> @flow
 852            >>> def my_flow():
 853            >>>     my_task.submit().wait()
 854
 855            Use the result from a task in a flow
 856
 857            >>> @flow
 858            >>> def my_flow():
 859            >>>     print(my_task.submit().result())
 860            >>>
 861            >>> my_flow()
 862            hello
 863
 864            Run an async task in an async flow
 865
 866            >>> @task
 867            >>> async def my_async_task():
 868            >>>     pass
 869            >>>
 870            >>> @flow
 871            >>> async def my_flow():
 872            >>>     await my_async_task.submit()
 873
 874            Run a sync task in an async flow
 875
 876            >>> @flow
 877            >>> async def my_flow():
 878            >>>     my_task.submit()
 879
 880            Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
 881            >>> @task
 882            >>> def task_1():
 883            >>>     pass
 884            >>>
 885            >>> @task
 886            >>> def task_2():
 887            >>>     pass
 888            >>>
 889            >>> @flow
 890            >>> def my_flow():
 891            >>>     x = task_1.submit()
 892            >>>
 893            >>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
 894            >>>     y = task_2.submit(wait_for=[x])
 895
 896        """
 897
 898        from prefect.engine import create_autonomous_task_run, enter_task_run_engine
 899
 900        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
 901        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
 902        return_type = "state" if return_state else "future"
 903        flow_run_context = FlowRunContext.get()
 904
 905        task_viz_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
 906        if task_viz_tracker:
 907            raise VisualizationUnsupportedError(
 908                "`task.submit()` is not currently supported by `flow.visualize()`"
 909            )
 910
 911        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING and not flow_run_context:
 912            create_autonomous_task_run_call = create_call(
 913                create_autonomous_task_run, task=self, parameters=parameters
 914            )
 915            if self.isasync:
 916                return from_async.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(
 917                    create_autonomous_task_run_call
 918                )
 919            else:
 920                return from_sync.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(
 921                    create_autonomous_task_run_call
 922                )
 923        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_NEW_ENGINE and flow_run_context:
 924            if self.isasync:
 925                return self._submit_async(
 926                    parameters=parameters,
 927                    flow_run_context=flow_run_context,
 928                    wait_for=wait_for,
 929                    return_state=return_state,
 930                )
 931            else:
 932                raise NotImplementedError(
 933                    "Submitting sync tasks with the new engine has not be implemented yet."
 934                )
 935
 936        else:
 937            return enter_task_run_engine(
 938                self,
 939                parameters=parameters,
 940                wait_for=wait_for,
 941                return_type=return_type,
 942                task_runner=None,  # Use the flow's task runner
 943                mapped=False,
 944            )
 945
 946    async def _submit_async(
 947        self,
 948        parameters: Dict[str, Any],
 949        flow_run_context: FlowRunContext,
 950        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]],
 951        return_state: bool,
 952    ):
 953        from prefect.new_task_engine import run_task_async
 954
 955        task_runner = flow_run_context.task_runner
 956
 957        task_run = await self.create_run(
 958            client=flow_run_context.client,
 959            flow_run_context=flow_run_context,
 960            parameters=parameters,
 961            wait_for=wait_for,
 962        )
 963
 964        future = PrefectFuture(
 965            name=task_run.name,
 966            key=uuid4(),
 967            task_runner=task_runner,
 968            asynchronous=(self.isasync and flow_run_context.flow.isasync),
 969        )
 970        future.task_run = task_run
 971        flow_run_context.task_run_futures.append(future)
 972        await task_runner.submit(
 973            key=future.key,
 974            call=partial(
 975                run_task_async,
 976                task=self,
 977                task_run=task_run,
 978                parameters=parameters,
 979                wait_for=wait_for,
 980                return_type="state",
 981            ),
 982        )
 983        # TODO: I don't like this. Can we move responsibility for creating the future
 984        # and setting this anyio.Event to the task runner?
 985        future._submitted.set()
 986
 987        if return_state:
 988            return await future.wait()
 989        else:
 990            return future
 991
 992    @overload
 993    def map(
 994        self: "Task[P, NoReturn]",
 995        *args: P.args,
 996        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
 997    ) -> List[PrefectFuture[None, Sync]]:
 998        # `NoReturn` matches if a type can't be inferred for the function which stops a
 999        # sync function from matching the `Coroutine` overload
1000        ...
1001

1003    def map(

1005        *args: P.args,
1006        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
1007    ) -> Awaitable[List[PrefectFuture[T, Async]]]:
1008        ...
1009
1010    @overload
1011    def map(
1012        self: "Task[P, T]",
1013        *args: P.args,
1014        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
1015    ) -> List[PrefectFuture[T, Sync]]:
1016        ...
1017

1019    def map(
1020        self: "Task[P, T]",
1021        *args: P.args,
1022        return_state: Literal[True],
1023        **kwargs: P.kwargs,
1024    ) -> List[State[T]]:
1025        ...
1026
1027    def map(
1028        self,
1029        *args: Any,
1030        return_state: bool = False,
1031        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
1032        **kwargs: Any,
1033    ) -> Any:
1034        """
1035        Submit a mapped run of the task to a worker.
1036
1037        Must be called within a flow function. If writing an async task, this
1038        call must be awaited.
1039
1040        Must be called with at least one iterable and all iterables must be
1041        the same length. Any arguments that are not iterable will be treated as
1042        a static value and each task run will receive the same value.
1043
1044        Will create as many task runs as the length of the iterable(s) in the
1045        backing API and submit the task runs to the flow's task runner. This
1046        call blocks if given a future as input while the future is resolved. It
1047        also blocks while the tasks are being submitted, once they are
1048        submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note
1049        that the `SequentialTaskRunner` does not implement parallel execution
1050        for sync tasks and they are fully resolved on submission.
1051
1052        Args:
1053            *args: Iterable and static arguments to run the tasks with
1054            return_state: Return a list of Prefect States that wrap the results
1055                of each task run.
1056            wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the
1057                task
1058            **kwargs: Keyword iterable arguments to run the task with
1059
1060        Returns:
1061            A list of futures allowing asynchronous access to the state of the
1062            tasks
1063
1064        Examples:
1065
1066            Define a task
1067
1068            >>> from prefect import task
1069            >>> @task
1070            >>> def my_task(x):
1071            >>>     return x + 1
1072
1073            Create mapped tasks
1074
1075            >>> from prefect import flow
1076            >>> @flow
1077            >>> def my_flow():
1078            >>>     my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1079
1080            Wait for all mapped tasks to finish
1081
1082            >>> @flow
1083            >>> def my_flow():
1084            >>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1085            >>>     for future in futures:
1086            >>>         future.wait()
1087            >>>     # Now all of the mapped tasks have finished
1088            >>>     my_task(10)
1089
1090            Use the result from mapped tasks in a flow
1091
1092            >>> @flow
1093            >>> def my_flow():
1094            >>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1095            >>>     for future in futures:
1096            >>>         print(future.result())
1097            >>> my_flow()
1098            2
1099            3
1100            4
1101
1102            Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
1103            >>> @task
1104            >>> def task_1(x):
1105            >>>     pass
1106            >>>
1107            >>> @task
1108            >>> def task_2(y):
1109            >>>     pass
1110            >>>
1111            >>> @flow
1112            >>> def my_flow():
1113            >>>     x = task_1.submit()
1114            >>>
1115            >>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
1116            >>>     y = task_2.map([1, 2, 3], wait_for=[x])
1117
1118            Use a non-iterable input as a constant across mapped tasks
1119            >>> @task
1120            >>> def display(prefix, item):
1121            >>>    print(prefix, item)
1122            >>>
1123            >>> @flow
1124            >>> def my_flow():
1125            >>>     display.map("Check it out: ", [1, 2, 3])
1126            >>>
1127            >>> my_flow()
1128            Check it out: 1
1129            Check it out: 2
1130            Check it out: 3
1131
1132            Use `unmapped` to treat an iterable argument as a constant
1133            >>> from prefect import unmapped
1134            >>>
1135            >>> @task
1136            >>> def add_n_to_items(items, n):
1137            >>>     return [item + n for item in items]
1138            >>>
1139            >>> @flow
1140            >>> def my_flow():
1141            >>>     return add_n_to_items.map(unmapped([10, 20]), n=[1, 2, 3])
1142            >>>
1143            >>> my_flow()
1144            [[11, 21], [12, 22], [13, 23]]
1145        """
1146
1147        from prefect.engine import begin_task_map, enter_task_run_engine
1148
1149        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict; do not apply defaults
1150        # since they should not be mapped over
1151        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs, apply_defaults=False)
1152        return_type = "state" if return_state else "future"
1153
1154        task_viz_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
1155        if task_viz_tracker:
1156            raise VisualizationUnsupportedError(
1157                "`task.map()` is not currently supported by `flow.visualize()`"
1158            )
1159
1160        if (
1161            PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING.value()
1162            and not FlowRunContext.get()
1163        ):
1164            map_call = create_call(
1165                begin_task_map,
1166                task=self,
1167                parameters=parameters,
1168                flow_run_context=None,
1169                wait_for=wait_for,
1170                return_type=return_type,
1171                task_runner=None,
1172                autonomous=True,
1173            )
1174            if self.isasync:
1175                return from_async.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(map_call)
1176            else:
1177                return from_sync.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(map_call)
1178
1179        return enter_task_run_engine(
1180            self,
1181            parameters=parameters,
1182            wait_for=wait_for,
1183            return_type=return_type,
1184            task_runner=None,
1185            mapped=True,
1186        )
1187
1188    def serve(self, task_runner: Optional[BaseTaskRunner] = None) -> "Task":
1189        """Serve the task using the provided task runner. This method is used to
1190        establish a websocket connection with the Prefect server and listen for
1191        submitted task runs to execute.
1192
1193        Args:
1194            task_runner: The task runner to use for serving the task. If not provided,
1195                the default ConcurrentTaskRunner will be used.
1196
1197        Examples:
1198            Serve a task using the default task runner
1199            >>> @task
1200            >>> def my_task():
1201            >>>     return 1
1202
1203            >>> my_task.serve()
1204        """
1205
1206        if not PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING:
1207            raise ValueError(
1208                "Task's `serve` method is an experimental feature and must be enabled with "
1209                "`prefect config set PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING=True`"
1210            )
1211
1212        from prefect.task_server import serve
1213
1214        serve(self, task_runner=task_runner)

A Prefect task definition.

!!! note We recommend using [the @task decorator][task] for most use-cases.

Wraps a function with an entrypoint to the Prefect engine. Calling this class within a flow function creates a new task run.

To preserve the input and output types, we use the generic type variables P and R for "Parameters" and "Returns" respectively.

Args: fn: The function defining the task. name: An optional name for the task; if not provided, the name will be inferred from the given function. description: An optional string description for the task. tags: An optional set of tags to be associated with runs of this task. These tags are combined with any tags defined by a prefect.tags context at task runtime. version: An optional string specifying the version of this task definition cache_key_fn: An optional callable that, given the task run context and call parameters, generates a string key; if the key matches a previous completed state, that state result will be restored instead of running the task again. cache_expiration: An optional amount of time indicating how long cached states for this task should be restorable; if not provided, cached states will never expire. task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables, or a function that returns a string. retries: An optional number of times to retry on task run failure. retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying the task after failure. This is only applicable if retries is nonzero. This setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays, or a callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list of retry delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to all retries. If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay before retrying. When passing a callable or a list, the number of configured retry delays cannot exceed 50. retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a retry can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd". persist_result: An optional toggle indicating whether the result of this task should be persisted to result storage. Defaults to None, which indicates that Prefect should choose whether the result should be persisted depending on the features being used. result_storage: An optional block to use to persist the result of this task. Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is called in. result_storage_key: An optional key to store the result in storage at when persisted. Defaults to a unique identifier. result_serializer: An optional serializer to use to serialize the result of this task for persistence. Defaults to the value set in the flow the task is called in. timeout_seconds: An optional number of seconds indicating a maximum runtime for the task. If the task exceeds this runtime, it will be marked as failed. log_prints: If set, print statements in the task will be redirected to the Prefect logger for the task run. Defaults to None, which indicates that the value from the flow should be used. refresh_cache: If set, cached results for the cache key are not used. Defaults to None, which indicates that a cached result from a previous execution with matching cache key is used. on_failure: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state. on_completion: An optional list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state. retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state. Should return True if the task should continue to its retry policy (e.g. retries=3), and False if the task should end as failed. Defaults to None, indicating the task should always continue to its retry policy. viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.

Task( fn: Callable[~P, ~R], name: Optional[str] = None, description: Optional[str] = None, tags: Optional[Iterable[str]] = None, version: Optional[str] = None, cache_key_fn: Optional[Callable[[prefect.context.TaskRunContext, Dict[str, Any]], Optional[str]]] = None, cache_expiration: Optional[datetime.timedelta] = None, task_run_name: Union[Callable[[], str], str, NoneType] = None, retries: Optional[int] = None, retry_delay_seconds: Union[float, int, List[float], Callable[[int], List[float]], NoneType] = None, retry_jitter_factor: Optional[float] = None, persist_result: Optional[bool] = None, result_storage: Union[prefect.filesystems.WritableFileSystem, str, NoneType] = None, result_serializer: Union[prefect.serializers.Serializer, str, NoneType] = None, result_storage_key: Optional[str] = None, cache_result_in_memory: bool = True, timeout_seconds: Union[int, float, NoneType] = None, log_prints: Optional[bool] = False, refresh_cache: Optional[bool] = None, on_completion: Optional[List[Callable[[Task, prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun, State], NoneType]]] = None, on_failure: Optional[List[Callable[[Task, prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun, State], NoneType]]] = None, retry_condition_fn: Optional[Callable[[Task, prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun, State], bool]] = None, viz_return_value: Optional[Any] = None) 
202    def __init__(
203        self,
204        fn: Callable[P, R],
205        name: Optional[str] = None,
206        description: Optional[str] = None,
207        tags: Optional[Iterable[str]] = None,
208        version: Optional[str] = None,
209        cache_key_fn: Optional[
210            Callable[["TaskRunContext", Dict[str, Any]], Optional[str]]
211        ] = None,
212        cache_expiration: Optional[datetime.timedelta] = None,
213        task_run_name: Optional[Union[Callable[[], str], str]] = None,
214        retries: Optional[int] = None,
215        retry_delay_seconds: Optional[
216            Union[
217                float,
218                int,
219                List[float],
220                Callable[[int], List[float]],
221            ]
222        ] = None,
223        retry_jitter_factor: Optional[float] = None,
224        persist_result: Optional[bool] = None,
225        result_storage: Optional[ResultStorage] = None,
226        result_serializer: Optional[ResultSerializer] = None,
227        result_storage_key: Optional[str] = None,
228        cache_result_in_memory: bool = True,
229        timeout_seconds: Union[int, float, None] = None,
230        log_prints: Optional[bool] = False,
231        refresh_cache: Optional[bool] = None,
232        on_completion: Optional[List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], None]]] = None,
233        on_failure: Optional[List[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], None]]] = None,
234        retry_condition_fn: Optional[Callable[["Task", TaskRun, State], bool]] = None,
235        viz_return_value: Optional[Any] = None,
236    ):
237        # Validate if hook passed is list and contains callables
238        hook_categories = [on_completion, on_failure]
239        hook_names = ["on_completion", "on_failure"]
240        for hooks, hook_name in zip(hook_categories, hook_names):
241            if hooks is not None:
242                if not hooks:
243                    raise ValueError(f"Empty list passed for '{hook_name}'")
244                try:
245                    hooks = list(hooks)
246                except TypeError:
247                    raise TypeError(
248                        f"Expected iterable for '{hook_name}'; got"
249                        f" {type(hooks).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
250                        f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
251                        f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
252                        " my_flow():\n\tpass"
253                    )
254
255                for hook in hooks:
256                    if not callable(hook):
257                        raise TypeError(
258                            f"Expected callables in '{hook_name}'; got"
259                            f" {type(hook).__name__} instead. Please provide a list of"
260                            f" hooks to '{hook_name}':\n\n"
261                            f"@flow({hook_name}=[hook1, hook2])\ndef"
262                            " my_flow():\n\tpass"
263                        )
264
265        if not callable(fn):
266            raise TypeError("'fn' must be callable")
267
268        self.description = description or inspect.getdoc(fn)
269        update_wrapper(self, fn)
270        self.fn = fn
271        self.isasync = inspect.iscoroutinefunction(self.fn)
272
273        if not name:
274            if not hasattr(self.fn, "__name__"):
275                self.name = type(self.fn).__name__
276            else:
277                self.name = self.fn.__name__
278        else:
279            self.name = name
280
281        if task_run_name is not None:
282            if not isinstance(task_run_name, str) and not callable(task_run_name):
283                raise TypeError(
284                    "Expected string or callable for 'task_run_name'; got"
285                    f" {type(task_run_name).__name__} instead."
286                )
287        self.task_run_name = task_run_name
288
289        self.version = version
290        self.log_prints = log_prints
291
292        raise_for_reserved_arguments(self.fn, ["return_state", "wait_for"])
293
294        self.tags = set(tags if tags else [])
295
296        if not hasattr(self.fn, "__qualname__"):
297            self.task_key = to_qualified_name(type(self.fn))
298        else:
299            try:
300                task_origin_hash = hash_objects(
301                    self.name, os.path.abspath(inspect.getsourcefile(self.fn))
302                )
303            except TypeError:
304                task_origin_hash = "unknown-source-file"
305
306            self.task_key = f"{self.fn.__qualname__}-{task_origin_hash}"
307
308        self.cache_key_fn = cache_key_fn
309        self.cache_expiration = cache_expiration
310        self.refresh_cache = refresh_cache
311
312        # TaskRunPolicy settings
313        # TODO: We can instantiate a `TaskRunPolicy` and add Pydantic bound checks to
314        #       validate that the user passes positive numbers here
315
316        self.retries = (
317            retries if retries is not None else PREFECT_TASK_DEFAULT_RETRIES.value()
318        )
319        if retry_delay_seconds is None:
320            retry_delay_seconds = PREFECT_TASK_DEFAULT_RETRY_DELAY_SECONDS.value()
321
322        if callable(retry_delay_seconds):
323            self.retry_delay_seconds = retry_delay_seconds(retries)
324        else:
325            self.retry_delay_seconds = retry_delay_seconds
326
327        if isinstance(self.retry_delay_seconds, list) and (
328            len(self.retry_delay_seconds) > 50
329        ):
330            raise ValueError("Can not configure more than 50 retry delays per task.")
331
332        if retry_jitter_factor is not None and retry_jitter_factor < 0:
333            raise ValueError("`retry_jitter_factor` must be >= 0.")
334
335        self.retry_jitter_factor = retry_jitter_factor
336        self.persist_result = persist_result
337        self.result_storage = result_storage
338        self.result_serializer = result_serializer
339        self.result_storage_key = result_storage_key
340        self.cache_result_in_memory = cache_result_in_memory
341        self.timeout_seconds = float(timeout_seconds) if timeout_seconds else None
342        self.on_completion = on_completion
343        self.on_failure = on_failure
344
345        # retry_condition_fn must be a callable or None. If it is neither, raise a TypeError
346        if retry_condition_fn is not None and not (callable(retry_condition_fn)):
347            raise TypeError(
348                "Expected `retry_condition_fn` to be callable, got"
349                f" {type(retry_condition_fn).__name__} instead."
350            )
351
352        self.retry_condition_fn = retry_condition_fn
353        self.viz_return_value = viz_return_value

393

396            description: A new description for the task.
397            tags: A new set of tags for the task. If given, existing tags are ignored,
398                not merged.
399            cache_key_fn: A new cache key function for the task.
400            cache_expiration: A new cache expiration time for the task.
401            task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided
402                as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables,
403                or a function that returns a string.
404            retries: A new number of times to retry on task run failure.
405            retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying
406                the task after failure. This is only applicable if `retries` is nonzero.
407                This setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays,
408                or a callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list
409                of retry delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to
410                all retries. If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay
411                before retrying. When passing a callable or a list, the number of
412                configured retry delays cannot exceed 50.
413            retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a
414                retry can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd".
415            persist_result: A new option for enabling or disabling result persistence.
416            result_storage: A new storage type to use for results.
417            result_serializer: A new serializer to use for results.
418            result_storage_key: A new key for the persisted result to be stored at.
419            timeout_seconds: A new maximum time for the task to complete in seconds.
420            log_prints: A new option for enabling or disabling redirection of `print` statements.
421            refresh_cache: A new option for enabling or disabling cache refresh.
422            on_completion: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state.
423            on_failure: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state.
424            retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state.
425                Should return `True` if the task should continue to its retry policy, and `False`
426                if the task should end as failed. Defaults to `None`, indicating the task should
427                always continue to its retry policy.
428            viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.

444

446            >>>

451            >>>         raise ValueError("Retry me please!")

453            >>>

455

457

459            >>> def my_task():
460            >>>     return 1
461            >>>
462            >>> @flow
463            >>> my_flow():
464            >>>     new_task = my_task.with_options(name="My new task")
465            >>>     new_task()
466        """
467        return Task(
468            fn=self.fn,
469            name=name or self.name,
470            description=description or self.description,
471            tags=tags or copy(self.tags),
472            cache_key_fn=cache_key_fn or self.cache_key_fn,
473            cache_expiration=cache_expiration or self.cache_expiration,

475            retries=retries if retries is not NotSet else self.retries,
