Create a new task from the current object, updating provided options.

Args: name: A new name for the task. description: A new description for the task. tags: A new set of tags for the task. If given, existing tags are ignored, not merged. cache_key_fn: A new cache key function for the task. cache_expiration: A new cache expiration time for the task. task_run_name: An optional name to distinguish runs of this task; this name can be provided as a string template with the task's keyword arguments as variables, or a function that returns a string. retries: A new number of times to retry on task run failure. retry_delay_seconds: Optionally configures how long to wait before retrying the task after failure. This is only applicable if retries is nonzero. This setting can either be a number of seconds, a list of retry delays, or a callable that, given the total number of retries, generates a list of retry delays. If a number of seconds, that delay will be applied to all retries. If a list, each retry will wait for the corresponding delay before retrying. When passing a callable or a list, the number of configured retry delays cannot exceed 50. retry_jitter_factor: An optional factor that defines the factor to which a retry can be jittered in order to avoid a "thundering herd". persist_result: A new option for enabling or disabling result persistence. result_storage: A new storage type to use for results. result_serializer: A new serializer to use for results. result_storage_key: A new key for the persisted result to be stored at. timeout_seconds: A new maximum time for the task to complete in seconds. log_prints: A new option for enabling or disabling redirection of print statements. refresh_cache: A new option for enabling or disabling cache refresh. on_completion: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a completed state. on_failure: A new list of callables to run when the task enters a failed state. retry_condition_fn: An optional callable run when a task run returns a Failed state. Should return True if the task should continue to its retry policy, and False if the task should end as failed. Defaults to None, indicating the task should always continue to its retry policy. viz_return_value: An optional value to return when the task dependency tree is visualized.

Returns: A new Task instance.

Examples:

Create a new task from an existing task and update the name

>>> @task(name="My task")
>>> def my_task():
>>>     return 1
>>>
>>> new_task = my_task.with_options(name="My new task")

Create a new task from an existing task and update the retry settings

>>> from random import randint
>>>
>>> @task(retries=1, retry_delay_seconds=5)
>>> def my_task():
>>>     x = randint(0, 5)
>>>     if x >= 3:  # Make a task that fails sometimes
>>>         raise ValueError("Retry me please!")
>>>     return x
>>>
>>> new_task = my_task.with_options(retries=5, retry_delay_seconds=2)

Use a task with updated options within a flow

>>> @task(name="My task")
>>> def my_task():
>>>     return 1
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> my_flow():
>>>     new_task = my_task.with_options(name="My new task")
>>>     new_task()
async def create_run( self, client: Union[prefect.client.orchestration.PrefectClient, prefect.client.orchestration.SyncPrefectClient, NoneType], parameters: Dict[str, Any] = None, flow_run_context: Optional[prefect.context.EngineContext] = None, parent_task_run_context: Optional[prefect.context.TaskRunContext] = None, wait_for: Optional[Iterable[prefect.futures.PrefectFuture]] = None, extra_task_inputs: Optional[Dict[str, Set[prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRunInput]]] = None) -> prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun: 
520    async def create_run(
521        self,
522        client: Optional[Union[PrefectClient, SyncPrefectClient]],
523        parameters: Dict[str, Any] = None,
524        flow_run_context: Optional[FlowRunContext] = None,
525        parent_task_run_context: Optional[TaskRunContext] = None,
526        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
527        extra_task_inputs: Optional[Dict[str, Set[TaskRunInput]]] = None,
528    ) -> TaskRun:
529        from prefect.utilities.engine import (
530            _dynamic_key_for_task_run,
531            _resolve_custom_task_run_name,
532            collect_task_run_inputs,
533        )
534
535        if flow_run_context is None:
536            flow_run_context = FlowRunContext.get()
537        if parent_task_run_context is None:
538            parent_task_run_context = TaskRunContext.get()
539        if parameters is None:
540            parameters = {}
541
542        try:
543            task_run_name = _resolve_custom_task_run_name(self, parameters)
544        except TypeError:
545            task_run_name = None
546
547        if flow_run_context:
548            dynamic_key = _dynamic_key_for_task_run(context=flow_run_context, task=self)
549        else:
550            dynamic_key = uuid4().hex
551
552        # collect task inputs
553        task_inputs = {
554            k: await collect_task_run_inputs(v) for k, v in parameters.items()
555        }
556
557        # check if this task has a parent task run based on running in another
558        # task run's existing context. A task run is only considered a parent if
559        # it is in the same flow run (because otherwise presumably the child is
560        # in a subflow, so the subflow serves as the parent) or if there is no
561        # flow run
562        if parent_task_run_context:
563            # there is no flow run
564            if not flow_run_context:
565                task_inputs["__parents__"] = [
566                    TaskRunResult(id=parent_task_run_context.task_run.id)
567                ]
568            # there is a flow run and the task run is in the same flow run
569            elif (
570                flow_run_context
571                and parent_task_run_context.task_run.flow_run_id
572                == flow_run_context.flow_run.id
573            ):
574                task_inputs["__parents__"] = [
575                    TaskRunResult(id=parent_task_run_context.task_run.id)
576                ]
577
578        if wait_for:
579            task_inputs["wait_for"] = await collect_task_run_inputs(wait_for)
580
581        # Join extra task inputs
582        for k, extras in (extra_task_inputs or {}).items():
583            task_inputs[k] = task_inputs[k].union(extras)
584
585        # create the task run
586        task_run = client.create_task_run(
587            task=self,
588            name=task_run_name,
589            flow_run_id=(
590                getattr(flow_run_context.flow_run, "id", None)
591                if flow_run_context and flow_run_context.flow_run
592                else None
593            ),
594            dynamic_key=str(dynamic_key),
595            state=Pending(),
596            task_inputs=task_inputs,
597            extra_tags=TagsContext.get().current_tags,
598        )
599        # the new engine uses sync clients but old engines use async clients
600        if inspect.isawaitable(task_run):
601            task_run = await task_run
602
603        if flow_run_context and flow_run_context.flow_run:
604            get_run_logger(flow_run_context).debug(
605                f"Created task run {task_run.name!r} for task {self.name!r}"
606            )
607        else:
608            logger.debug(f"Created task run {task_run.name!r} for task {self.name!r}")
609
610        return task_run
def submit( self, *args: Any, return_state: bool = False, wait_for: Optional[Iterable[prefect.futures.PrefectFuture]] = None, **kwargs: Any) -> Union[prefect.futures.PrefectFuture, Awaitable[prefect.futures.PrefectFuture], prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun, Awaitable[prefect.client.schemas.objects.TaskRun]]: 
800    def submit(
801        self,
802        *args: Any,
803        return_state: bool = False,
804        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
805        **kwargs: Any,
806    ) -> Union[PrefectFuture, Awaitable[PrefectFuture], TaskRun, Awaitable[TaskRun]]:
807        """
808        Submit a run of the task to the engine.
809
810        If writing an async task, this call must be awaited.
811
812        If called from within a flow function,
813
814        Will create a new task run in the backing API and submit the task to the flow's
815        task runner. This call only blocks execution while the task is being submitted,
816        once it is submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note
817        that the `SequentialTaskRunner` does not implement parallel execution for sync tasks
818        and they are fully resolved on submission.
819
820        Args:
821            *args: Arguments to run the task with
822            return_state: Return the result of the flow run wrapped in a
823                Prefect State.
824            wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the task
825            **kwargs: Keyword arguments to run the task with
826
827        Returns:
828            If `return_state` is False a future allowing asynchronous access to
829                the state of the task
830            If `return_state` is True a future wrapped in a Prefect State allowing asynchronous access to
831                the state of the task
832
833        Examples:
834
835            Define a task
836
837            >>> from prefect import task
838            >>> @task
839            >>> def my_task():
840            >>>     return "hello"
841
842            Run a task in a flow
843
844            >>> from prefect import flow
845            >>> @flow
846            >>> def my_flow():
847            >>>     my_task.submit()
848
849            Wait for a task to finish
850
851            >>> @flow
852            >>> def my_flow():
853            >>>     my_task.submit().wait()
854
855            Use the result from a task in a flow
856
857            >>> @flow
858            >>> def my_flow():
859            >>>     print(my_task.submit().result())
860            >>>
861            >>> my_flow()
862            hello
863
864            Run an async task in an async flow
865
866            >>> @task
867            >>> async def my_async_task():
868            >>>     pass
869            >>>
870            >>> @flow
871            >>> async def my_flow():
872            >>>     await my_async_task.submit()
873
874            Run a sync task in an async flow
875
876            >>> @flow
877            >>> async def my_flow():
878            >>>     my_task.submit()
879
880            Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
881            >>> @task
882            >>> def task_1():
883            >>>     pass
884            >>>
885            >>> @task
886            >>> def task_2():
887            >>>     pass
888            >>>
889            >>> @flow
890            >>> def my_flow():
891            >>>     x = task_1.submit()
892            >>>
893            >>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
894            >>>     y = task_2.submit(wait_for=[x])
895
896        """
897
898        from prefect.engine import create_autonomous_task_run, enter_task_run_engine
899
900        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict
901        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs)
902        return_type = "state" if return_state else "future"
903        flow_run_context = FlowRunContext.get()
904
905        task_viz_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
906        if task_viz_tracker:
907            raise VisualizationUnsupportedError(
908                "`task.submit()` is not currently supported by `flow.visualize()`"
909            )
910
911        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING and not flow_run_context:
912            create_autonomous_task_run_call = create_call(
913                create_autonomous_task_run, task=self, parameters=parameters
914            )
915            if self.isasync:
916                return from_async.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(
917                    create_autonomous_task_run_call
918                )
919            else:
920                return from_sync.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(
921                    create_autonomous_task_run_call
922                )
923        if PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_NEW_ENGINE and flow_run_context:
924            if self.isasync:
925                return self._submit_async(
926                    parameters=parameters,
927                    flow_run_context=flow_run_context,
928                    wait_for=wait_for,
929                    return_state=return_state,
930                )
931            else:
932                raise NotImplementedError(
933                    "Submitting sync tasks with the new engine has not be implemented yet."
934                )
935
936        else:
937            return enter_task_run_engine(
938                self,
939                parameters=parameters,
940                wait_for=wait_for,
941                return_type=return_type,
942                task_runner=None,  # Use the flow's task runner
943                mapped=False,
944            )

Submit a run of the task to the engine.

If writing an async task, this call must be awaited.

If called from within a flow function,

Will create a new task run in the backing API and submit the task to the flow's task runner. This call only blocks execution while the task is being submitted, once it is submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note that the SequentialTaskRunner does not implement parallel execution for sync tasks and they are fully resolved on submission.

Args: args: Arguments to run the task with return_state: Return the result of the flow run wrapped in a Prefect State. wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the task *kwargs: Keyword arguments to run the task with

Returns: If return_state is False a future allowing asynchronous access to the state of the task If return_state is True a future wrapped in a Prefect State allowing asynchronous access to the state of the task

Examples:

Define a task

>>> from prefect import task
>>> @task
>>> def my_task():
>>>     return "hello"

Run a task in a flow

>>> from prefect import flow
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     my_task.submit()

Wait for a task to finish

>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     my_task.submit().wait()

Use the result from a task in a flow

>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     print(my_task.submit().result())
>>>
>>> my_flow()
hello

Run an async task in an async flow

>>> @task
>>> async def my_async_task():
>>>     pass
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> async def my_flow():
>>>     await my_async_task.submit()

Run a sync task in an async flow

>>> @flow
>>> async def my_flow():
>>>     my_task.submit()

Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
>>> @task
>>> def task_1():
>>>     pass
>>>
>>> @task
>>> def task_2():
>>>     pass
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     x = task_1.submit()
>>>
>>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
>>>     y = task_2.submit(wait_for=[x])
def map( self, *args: Any, return_state: bool = False, wait_for: Optional[Iterable[prefect.futures.PrefectFuture]] = None, **kwargs: Any) -> Any: 
1027    def map(
1028        self,
1029        *args: Any,
1030        return_state: bool = False,
1031        wait_for: Optional[Iterable[PrefectFuture]] = None,
1032        **kwargs: Any,
1033    ) -> Any:
1034        """
1035        Submit a mapped run of the task to a worker.
1036
1037        Must be called within a flow function. If writing an async task, this
1038        call must be awaited.
1039
1040        Must be called with at least one iterable and all iterables must be
1041        the same length. Any arguments that are not iterable will be treated as
1042        a static value and each task run will receive the same value.
1043
1044        Will create as many task runs as the length of the iterable(s) in the
1045        backing API and submit the task runs to the flow's task runner. This
1046        call blocks if given a future as input while the future is resolved. It
1047        also blocks while the tasks are being submitted, once they are
1048        submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note
1049        that the `SequentialTaskRunner` does not implement parallel execution
1050        for sync tasks and they are fully resolved on submission.
1051
1052        Args:
1053            *args: Iterable and static arguments to run the tasks with
1054            return_state: Return a list of Prefect States that wrap the results
1055                of each task run.
1056            wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the
1057                task
1058            **kwargs: Keyword iterable arguments to run the task with
1059
1060        Returns:
1061            A list of futures allowing asynchronous access to the state of the
1062            tasks
1063
1064        Examples:
1065
1066            Define a task
1067
1068            >>> from prefect import task
1069            >>> @task
1070            >>> def my_task(x):
1071            >>>     return x + 1
1072
1073            Create mapped tasks
1074
1075            >>> from prefect import flow
1076            >>> @flow
1077            >>> def my_flow():
1078            >>>     my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1079
1080            Wait for all mapped tasks to finish
1081
1082            >>> @flow
1083            >>> def my_flow():
1084            >>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1085            >>>     for future in futures:
1086            >>>         future.wait()
1087            >>>     # Now all of the mapped tasks have finished
1088            >>>     my_task(10)
1089
1090            Use the result from mapped tasks in a flow
1091
1092            >>> @flow
1093            >>> def my_flow():
1094            >>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
1095            >>>     for future in futures:
1096            >>>         print(future.result())
1097            >>> my_flow()
1098            2
1099            3
1100            4
1101
1102            Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
1103            >>> @task
1104            >>> def task_1(x):
1105            >>>     pass
1106            >>>
1107            >>> @task
1108            >>> def task_2(y):
1109            >>>     pass
1110            >>>
1111            >>> @flow
1112            >>> def my_flow():
1113            >>>     x = task_1.submit()
1114            >>>
1115            >>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
1116            >>>     y = task_2.map([1, 2, 3], wait_for=[x])
1117
1118            Use a non-iterable input as a constant across mapped tasks
1119            >>> @task
1120            >>> def display(prefix, item):
1121            >>>    print(prefix, item)
1122            >>>
1123            >>> @flow
1124            >>> def my_flow():
1125            >>>     display.map("Check it out: ", [1, 2, 3])
1126            >>>
1127            >>> my_flow()
1128            Check it out: 1
1129            Check it out: 2
1130            Check it out: 3
1131
1132            Use `unmapped` to treat an iterable argument as a constant
1133            >>> from prefect import unmapped
1134            >>>
1135            >>> @task
1136            >>> def add_n_to_items(items, n):
1137            >>>     return [item + n for item in items]
1138            >>>
1139            >>> @flow
1140            >>> def my_flow():
1141            >>>     return add_n_to_items.map(unmapped([10, 20]), n=[1, 2, 3])
1142            >>>
1143            >>> my_flow()
1144            [[11, 21], [12, 22], [13, 23]]
1145        """
1146
1147        from prefect.engine import begin_task_map, enter_task_run_engine
1148
1149        # Convert the call args/kwargs to a parameter dict; do not apply defaults
1150        # since they should not be mapped over
1151        parameters = get_call_parameters(self.fn, args, kwargs, apply_defaults=False)
1152        return_type = "state" if return_state else "future"
1153
1154        task_viz_tracker = get_task_viz_tracker()
1155        if task_viz_tracker:
1156            raise VisualizationUnsupportedError(
1157                "`task.map()` is not currently supported by `flow.visualize()`"
1158            )
1159
1160        if (
1161            PREFECT_EXPERIMENTAL_ENABLE_TASK_SCHEDULING.value()
1162            and not FlowRunContext.get()
1163        ):
1164            map_call = create_call(
1165                begin_task_map,
1166                task=self,
1167                parameters=parameters,
1168                flow_run_context=None,
1169                wait_for=wait_for,
1170                return_type=return_type,
1171                task_runner=None,
1172                autonomous=True,
1173            )
1174            if self.isasync:
1175                return from_async.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(map_call)
1176            else:
1177                return from_sync.wait_for_call_in_loop_thread(map_call)
1178
1179        return enter_task_run_engine(
1180            self,
1181            parameters=parameters,
1182            wait_for=wait_for,
1183            return_type=return_type,
1184            task_runner=None,
1185            mapped=True,
1186        )

Submit a mapped run of the task to a worker.

Must be called within a flow function. If writing an async task, this call must be awaited.

Must be called with at least one iterable and all iterables must be the same length. Any arguments that are not iterable will be treated as a static value and each task run will receive the same value.

Will create as many task runs as the length of the iterable(s) in the backing API and submit the task runs to the flow's task runner. This call blocks if given a future as input while the future is resolved. It also blocks while the tasks are being submitted, once they are submitted, the flow function will continue executing. However, note that the SequentialTaskRunner does not implement parallel execution for sync tasks and they are fully resolved on submission.

Args: args: Iterable and static arguments to run the tasks with return_state: Return a list of Prefect States that wrap the results of each task run. wait_for: Upstream task futures to wait for before starting the task *kwargs: Keyword iterable arguments to run the task with

Returns: A list of futures allowing asynchronous access to the state of the tasks

Examples:

Define a task

>>> from prefect import task
>>> @task
>>> def my_task(x):
>>>     return x + 1

Create mapped tasks

>>> from prefect import flow
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     my_task.map([1, 2, 3])

Wait for all mapped tasks to finish

>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
>>>     for future in futures:
>>>         future.wait()
>>>     # Now all of the mapped tasks have finished
>>>     my_task(10)

Use the result from mapped tasks in a flow

>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     futures = my_task.map([1, 2, 3])
>>>     for future in futures:
>>>         print(future.result())
>>> my_flow()
2
3
4

Enforce ordering between tasks that do not exchange data
>>> @task
>>> def task_1(x):
>>>     pass
>>>
>>> @task
>>> def task_2(y):
>>>     pass
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     x = task_1.submit()
>>>
>>>     # task 2 will wait for task_1 to complete
>>>     y = task_2.map([1, 2, 3], wait_for=[x])

Use a non-iterable input as a constant across mapped tasks
>>> @task
>>> def display(prefix, item):
>>>    print(prefix, item)
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     display.map("Check it out: ", [1, 2, 3])
>>>
>>> my_flow()
Check it out: 1
Check it out: 2
Check it out: 3

Use `unmapped` to treat an iterable argument as a constant
>>> from prefect import unmapped
>>>
>>> @task
>>> def add_n_to_items(items, n):
>>>     return [item + n for item in items]
>>>
>>> @flow
>>> def my_flow():
>>>     return add_n_to_items.map(unmapped([10, 20]), n=[1, 2, 3])
>>>
>>> my_flow()
[[11, 21], [12, 22], [13, 23]]

@sync_compatible
async def deploy( *deployments: prefect.deployments.runner.RunnerDeployment, work_pool_name: Optional[str] = None, image: Union[str, prefect.deployments.runner.DeploymentImage, NoneType] = None, build: bool = True, push: bool = True, print_next_steps_message: bool = True, ignore_warnings: bool = False) -> List[uuid.UUID]: 
 848@sync_compatible
 849async def deploy(
 850    *deployments: RunnerDeployment,
 851    work_pool_name: Optional[str] = None,
 852    image: Optional[Union[str, DeploymentImage]] = None,
 853    build: bool = True,
 854    push: bool = True,
 855    print_next_steps_message: bool = True,
 856    ignore_warnings: bool = False,
 857) -> List[UUID]:
 858    """
 859    Deploy the provided list of deployments to dynamic infrastructure via a
 860    work pool.
 861
 862    By default, calling this function will build a Docker image for the deployments, push it to a
 863    registry, and create each deployment via the Prefect API that will run the corresponding
 864    flow on the given schedule.
 865
 866    If you want to use an existing image, you can pass `build=False` to skip building and pushing
 867    an image.
 868
 869    Args:
 870        *deployments: A list of deployments to deploy.
 871        work_pool_name: The name of the work pool to use for these deployments. Defaults to
 872            the value of `PREFECT_DEFAULT_WORK_POOL_NAME`.
 873        image: The name of the Docker image to build, including the registry and
 874            repository. Pass a DeploymentImage instance to customize the Dockerfile used
 875            and build arguments.
 876        build: Whether or not to build a new image for the flow. If False, the provided
 877            image will be used as-is and pulled at runtime.
 878        push: Whether or not to skip pushing the built image to a registry.
 879        print_next_steps_message: Whether or not to print a message with next steps
 880            after deploying the deployments.
 881
 882    Returns:
 883        A list of deployment IDs for the created/updated deployments.
 884
 885    Examples:
 886        Deploy a group of flows to a work pool:
 887
 888        ```python
 889        from prefect import deploy, flow
 890
 891        @flow(log_prints=True)
 892        def local_flow():
 893            print("I'm a locally defined flow!")
 894
 895        if __name__ == "__main__":
 896            deploy(
 897                local_flow.to_deployment(name="example-deploy-local-flow"),
 898                flow.from_source(
 899                    source="https://github.com/org/repo.git",
 900                    entrypoint="flows.py:my_flow",
 901                ).to_deployment(
 902                    name="example-deploy-remote-flow",
 903                ),
 904                work_pool_name="my-work-pool",
 905                image="my-registry/my-image:dev",
 906            )
 907        ```
 908    """
 909    work_pool_name = work_pool_name or PREFECT_DEFAULT_WORK_POOL_NAME.value()
 910
 911    if not image and not all(
 912        d.storage or d.entrypoint_type == EntrypointType.MODULE_PATH
 913        for d in deployments
 914    ):
 915        raise ValueError(
 916            "Either an image or remote storage location must be provided when deploying"
 917            " a deployment."
 918        )
 919
 920    if not work_pool_name:
 921        raise ValueError(
 922            "A work pool name must be provided when deploying a deployment. Either"
 923            " provide a work pool name when calling `deploy` or set"
 924            " `PREFECT_DEFAULT_WORK_POOL_NAME` in your profile."
 925        )
 926
 927    if image and isinstance(image, str):
 928        image_name, image_tag = parse_image_tag(image)
 929        image = DeploymentImage(name=image_name, tag=image_tag)
 930
 931    try:
 932        async with get_client() as client:
 933            work_pool = await client.read_work_pool(work_pool_name)
 934    except ObjectNotFound as exc:
 935        raise ValueError(
 936            f"Could not find work pool {work_pool_name!r}. Please create it before"
 937            " deploying this flow."
 938        ) from exc
 939
 940    is_docker_based_work_pool = get_from_dict(
 941        work_pool.base_job_template, "variables.properties.image", False
 942    )
 943    is_block_based_work_pool = get_from_dict(
 944        work_pool.base_job_template, "variables.properties.block", False
 945    )
 946    # carve out an exception for block based work pools that only have a block in their base job template
 947    console = Console()
 948    if not is_docker_based_work_pool and not is_block_based_work_pool:
 949        if image:
 950            raise ValueError(
 951                f"Work pool {work_pool_name!r} does not support custom Docker images."
 952                " Please use a work pool with an `image` variable in its base job template"
 953                " or specify a remote storage location for the flow with `.from_source`."
 954                " If you are attempting to deploy a flow to a local process work pool,"
 955                " consider using `flow.serve` instead. See the documentation for more"
 956                " information: https://docs.prefect.io/latest/concepts/flows/#serving-a-flow"
 957            )
 958        elif work_pool.type == "process" and not ignore_warnings:
 959            console.print(
 960                "Looks like you're deploying to a process work pool. If you're creating a"
 961                " deployment for local development, calling `.serve` on your flow is a great"
 962                " way to get started. See the documentation for more information:"
 963                " https://docs.prefect.io/latest/concepts/flows/#serving-a-flow. "
 964                " Set `ignore_warnings=True` to suppress this message.",
 965                style="yellow",
 966            )
 967
 968    is_managed_pool = work_pool.is_managed_pool
 969    if is_managed_pool:
 970        build = False
 971        push = False
 972
 973    if image and build:
 974        with Progress(
 975            SpinnerColumn(),
 976            TextColumn(f"Building image {image.reference}..."),
 977            transient=True,
 978            console=console,
 979        ) as progress:
 980            docker_build_task = progress.add_task("docker_build", total=1)
 981            image.build()
 982
 983            progress.update(docker_build_task, completed=1)
 984            console.print(
 985                f"Successfully built image {image.reference!r}", style="green"
 986            )
 987
 988    if image and build and push:
 989        with Progress(
 990            SpinnerColumn(),
 991            TextColumn("Pushing image..."),
 992            transient=True,
 993            console=console,
 994        ) as progress:
 995            docker_push_task = progress.add_task("docker_push", total=1)
 996
 997            image.push()
 998
 999            progress.update(docker_push_task, completed=1)
1000
1001        console.print(f"Successfully pushed image {image.reference!r}", style="green")
1002
1003    deployment_exceptions = []
1004    deployment_ids = []
1005    image_ref = image.reference if image else None
1006    for deployment in track(
1007        deployments,
1008        description="Creating/updating deployments...",
1009        console=console,
1010        transient=True,
1011    ):
1012        try:
1013            deployment_ids.append(
1014                await deployment.apply(image=image_ref, work_pool_name=work_pool_name)
1015            )
1016        except Exception as exc:
1017            if len(deployments) == 1:
1018                raise
1019            deployment_exceptions.append({"deployment": deployment, "exc": exc})
1020
1021    if deployment_exceptions:
1022        console.print(
1023            "Encountered errors while creating/updating deployments:\n",
1024            style="orange_red1",
1025        )
1026    else:
1027        console.print("Successfully created/updated all deployments!\n", style="green")
1028
1029    complete_failure = len(deployment_exceptions) == len(deployments)
1030
1031    table = Table(
1032        title="Deployments",
1033        show_lines=True,
1034    )
1035
1036    table.add_column(header="Name", style="blue", no_wrap=True)
1037    table.add_column(header="Status", style="blue", no_wrap=True)
1038    table.add_column(header="Details", style="blue")
1039
1040    for deployment in deployments:
1041        errored_deployment = next(
1042            (d for d in deployment_exceptions if d["deployment"] == deployment),
1043            None,
1044        )
1045        if errored_deployment:
1046            table.add_row(
1047                f"{deployment.flow_name}/{deployment.name}",
1048                "failed",
1049                str(errored_deployment["exc"]),
1050                style="red",
1051            )
1052        else:
1053            table.add_row(f"{deployment.flow_name}/{deployment.name}", "applied")
1054    console.print(table)
1055
1056    if print_next_steps_message and not complete_failure:
1057        if not work_pool.is_push_pool and not work_pool.is_managed_pool:
1058            console.print(
1059                "\nTo execute flow runs from these deployments, start a worker in a"
1060                " separate terminal that pulls work from the"
1061                f" {work_pool_name!r} work pool:"
1062            )
1063            console.print(
1064                f"\n\t$ prefect worker start --pool {work_pool_name!r}",
1065                style="blue",
1066            )
1067        console.print(
1068            "\nTo trigger any of these deployments, use the"
1069            " following command:\n[blue]\n\t$ prefect deployment run"
1070            " [DEPLOYMENT_NAME]\n[/]"
1071        )
1072
1073        if PREFECT_UI_URL:
1074            console.print(
1075                "\nYou can also trigger your deployments via the Prefect UI:"
1076                f" [blue]{PREFECT_UI_URL.value()}/deployments[/]\n"
1077            )
1078
1079    return deployment_ids

@sync_compatible

1003@sync_compatible
1004@deprecated_parameter(
1005    "flow_run_id", start_date="Dec 2023", help="Use `suspend_flow_run` instead."
1006)
1007@deprecated_parameter(
1008    "reschedule",
1009    start_date="Dec 2023",
1010    when=lambda p: p is True,
1011    help="Use `suspend_flow_run` instead.",
1012)
1013@experimental_parameter(
1014    "wait_for_input", group="flow_run_input", when=lambda y: y is not None
1015)
1016async def pause_flow_run(
1017    wait_for_input: Optional[Type[T]] = None,
1018    flow_run_id: UUID = None,
1019    timeout: int = 3600,
1020    poll_interval: int = 10,
1021    reschedule: bool = False,
1022    key: str = None,
1023) -> Optional[T]:
1024    """
1025    Pauses the current flow run by blocking execution until resumed.
1026
1027    When called within a flow run, execution will block and no downstream tasks will
1028    run until the flow is resumed. Task runs that have already started will continue
1029    running. A timeout parameter can be passed that will fail the flow run if it has not
1030    been resumed within the specified time.
1031
1032    Args:
1033        flow_run_id: a flow run id. If supplied, this function will attempt to pause
1034            the specified flow run outside of the flow run process. When paused, the
1035            flow run will continue execution until the NEXT task is orchestrated, at
1036            which point the flow will exit. Any tasks that have already started will
1037            run until completion. When resumed, the flow run will be rescheduled to
1038            finish execution. In order pause a flow run in this way, the flow needs to
1039            have an associated deployment and results need to be configured with the
1040            `persist_results` option.
1041        timeout: the number of seconds to wait for the flow to be resumed before
1042            failing. Defaults to 1 hour (3600 seconds). If the pause timeout exceeds
1043            any configured flow-level timeout, the flow might fail even after resuming.
1044        poll_interval: The number of seconds between checking whether the flow has been
1045            resumed. Defaults to 10 seconds.
1046        reschedule: Flag that will reschedule the flow run if resumed. Instead of
1047            blocking execution, the flow will gracefully exit (with no result returned)
1048            instead. To use this flag, a flow needs to have an associated deployment and
1049            results need to be configured with the `persist_results` option.
1050        key: An optional key to prevent calling pauses more than once. This defaults to
1051            the number of pauses observed by the flow so far, and prevents pauses that
1052            use the "reschedule" option from running the same pause twice. A custom key
1053            can be supplied for custom pausing behavior.
1054        wait_for_input: a subclass of `RunInput` or any type supported by
1055            Pydantic. If provided when the flow pauses, the flow will wait for the
1056            input to be provided before resuming. If the flow is resumed without
1057            providing the input, the flow will fail. If the flow is resumed with the
1058            input, the flow will resume and the input will be loaded and returned
1059            from this function.
1060
1061    Example:
1062    ```python
1063    @task
1064    def task_one():
1065        for i in range(3):
1066            sleep(1)
1067
1068    @flow
1069    def my_flow():
1070        terminal_state = task_one.submit(return_state=True)
1071        if terminal_state.type == StateType.COMPLETED:
1072            print("Task one succeeded! Pausing flow run..")
1073            pause_flow_run(timeout=2)
1074        else:
1075            print("Task one failed. Skipping pause flow run..")
1076    ```
1077
1078    """
1079    if flow_run_id:
1080        if wait_for_input is not None:
1081            raise RuntimeError("Cannot wait for input when pausing out of process.")
1082
1083        return await _out_of_process_pause(
1084            flow_run_id=flow_run_id,
1085            timeout=timeout,
1086            reschedule=reschedule,
1087            key=key,
1088        )
1089    else:
1090        return await _in_process_pause(
1091            timeout=timeout,
1092            poll_interval=poll_interval,
1093            reschedule=reschedule,
1094            key=key,
1095            wait_for_input=wait_for_input,
1096        )

Pauses the current flow run by blocking execution until resumed.

When called within a flow run, execution will block and no downstream tasks will run until the flow is resumed. Task runs that have already started will continue running. A timeout parameter can be passed that will fail the flow run if it has not been resumed within the specified time.

Args: flow_run_id: a flow run id. If supplied, this function will attempt to pause the specified flow run outside of the flow run process. When paused, the flow run will continue execution until the NEXT task is orchestrated, at which point the flow will exit. Any tasks that have already started will run until completion. When resumed, the flow run will be rescheduled to finish execution. In order pause a flow run in this way, the flow needs to have an associated deployment and results need to be configured with the persist_results option. timeout: the number of seconds to wait for the flow to be resumed before failing. Defaults to 1 hour (3600 seconds). If the pause timeout exceeds any configured flow-level timeout, the flow might fail even after resuming. poll_interval: The number of seconds between checking whether the flow has been resumed. Defaults to 10 seconds. reschedule: Flag that will reschedule the flow run if resumed. Instead of blocking execution, the flow will gracefully exit (with no result returned) instead. To use this flag, a flow needs to have an associated deployment and results need to be configured with the persist_results option. key: An optional key to prevent calling pauses more than once. This defaults to the number of pauses observed by the flow so far, and prevents pauses that use the "reschedule" option from running the same pause twice. A custom key can be supplied for custom pausing behavior. wait_for_input: a subclass of RunInput or any type supported by Pydantic. If provided when the flow pauses, the flow will wait for the input to be provided before resuming. If the flow is resumed without providing the input, the flow will fail. If the flow is resumed with the input, the flow will resume and the input will be loaded and returned from this function.

Example:

@task
def task_one():
    for i in range(3):
        sleep(1)

@flow
def my_flow():
    terminal_state = task_one.submit(return_state=True)
    if terminal_state.type == StateType.COMPLETED:
        print("Task one succeeded! Pausing flow run..")
        pause_flow_run(timeout=2)
    else:
        print("Task one failed. Skipping pause flow run..")
@sync_compatible
async def resume_flow_run(flow_run_id, run_input: Optional[Dict] = None): 
1347@sync_compatible
1348async def resume_flow_run(flow_run_id, run_input: Optional[Dict] = None):
1349    """
1350    Resumes a paused flow.
1351
1352    Args:
1353        flow_run_id: the flow_run_id to resume
1354        run_input: a dictionary of inputs to provide to the flow run.
1355    """
1356    client = get_client()
1357    async with client:
1358        flow_run = await client.read_flow_run(flow_run_id)
1359
1360        if not flow_run.state.is_paused():
1361            raise NotPausedError("Cannot resume a run that isn't paused!")
1362
1363        response = await client.resume_flow_run(flow_run_id, run_input=run_input)
1364
1365    if response.status == SetStateStatus.REJECT:
1366        if response.state.type == StateType.FAILED:
1367            raise FlowPauseTimeout("Flow run can no longer be resumed.")
1368        else:
1369            raise RuntimeError(f"Cannot resume this run: {response.details.reason}")

@sync_compatible
@inject_client
@experimental_parameter('wait_for_input', group='flow_run_input', when=lambda y: y is not None)
async def suspend_flow_run( wait_for_input: Optional[Type[~T]] = None, flow_run_id: Optional[uuid.UUID] = None, timeout: Optional[int] = 3600, key: Optional[str] = None, client: prefect.client.orchestration.PrefectClient = None) -> Optional[~T]: 
1238@sync_compatible
1239@inject_client
1240@experimental_parameter(
1241    "wait_for_input", group="flow_run_input", when=lambda y: y is not None
1242)
1243async def suspend_flow_run(
1244    wait_for_input: Optional[Type[T]] = None,
1245    flow_run_id: Optional[UUID] = None,
1246    timeout: Optional[int] = 3600,
1247    key: Optional[str] = None,
1248    client: PrefectClient = None,
1249) -> Optional[T]:
1250    """
1251    Suspends a flow run by stopping code execution until resumed.
1252
1253    When suspended, the flow run will continue execution until the NEXT task is
1254    orchestrated, at which point the flow will exit. Any tasks that have
1255    already started will run until completion. When resumed, the flow run will
1256    be rescheduled to finish execution. In order suspend a flow run in this
1257    way, the flow needs to have an associated deployment and results need to be
1258    configured with the `persist_results` option.
1259
1260    Args:
1261        flow_run_id: a flow run id. If supplied, this function will attempt to
1262            suspend the specified flow run. If not supplied will attempt to
1263            suspend the current flow run.
1264        timeout: the number of seconds to wait for the flow to be resumed before
1265            failing. Defaults to 1 hour (3600 seconds). If the pause timeout
1266            exceeds any configured flow-level timeout, the flow might fail even
1267            after resuming.
1268        key: An optional key to prevent calling suspend more than once. This
1269            defaults to a random string and prevents suspends from running the
1270            same suspend twice. A custom key can be supplied for custom
1271            suspending behavior.
1272        wait_for_input: a subclass of `RunInput` or any type supported by
1273            Pydantic. If provided when the flow suspends, the flow will remain
1274            suspended until receiving the input before resuming. If the flow is
1275            resumed without providing the input, the flow will fail. If the flow is
1276            resumed with the input, the flow will resume and the input will be
1277            loaded and returned from this function.
1278    """
1279    context = FlowRunContext.get()
1280
1281    if flow_run_id is None:
1282        if TaskRunContext.get():
1283            raise RuntimeError("Cannot suspend task runs.")
1284
1285        if context is None or context.flow_run is None:
1286            raise RuntimeError(
1287                "Flow runs can only be suspended from within a flow run."
1288            )
1289
1290        logger = get_run_logger(context=context)
1291        logger.info(
1292            "Suspending flow run, execution will be rescheduled when this flow run is"
1293            " resumed."
1294        )
1295        flow_run_id = context.flow_run.id
1296        suspending_current_flow_run = True
1297        pause_counter = _observed_flow_pauses(context)
1298        pause_key = key or str(pause_counter)
1299    else:
1300        # Since we're suspending another flow run we need to generate a pause
1301        # key that won't conflict with whatever suspends/pauses that flow may
1302        # have. Since this method won't be called during that flow run it's
1303        # okay that this is non-deterministic.
1304        suspending_current_flow_run = False
1305        pause_key = key or str(uuid4())
1306
1307    proposed_state = Suspended(timeout_seconds=timeout, pause_key=pause_key)
1308
1309    if wait_for_input:
1310        wait_for_input = run_input_subclass_from_type(wait_for_input)
1311        run_input_keyset = keyset_from_paused_state(proposed_state)
1312        proposed_state.state_details.run_input_keyset = run_input_keyset
1313
1314    try:
1315        state = await propose_state(
1316            client=client,
1317            state=proposed_state,
1318            flow_run_id=flow_run_id,
1319        )
1320    except Abort as exc:
1321        # Aborted requests mean the suspension is not allowed
1322        raise RuntimeError(f"Flow run cannot be suspended: {exc}")
1323
1324    if state.is_running():
1325        # The orchestrator rejected the suspended state which means that this
1326        # suspend has happened before and the flow run has been resumed.
1327        if wait_for_input:
1328            # The flow run wanted input, so we need to load it and return it
1329            # to the user.
1330            return await wait_for_input.load(run_input_keyset)
1331        return
1332
1333    if not state.is_paused():
1334        # If we receive anything but a PAUSED state, we are unable to continue
1335        raise RuntimeError(
1336            f"Flow run cannot be suspended. Received unexpected state from API: {state}"
1337        )
1338
1339    if wait_for_input:
1340        await wait_for_input.save(run_input_keyset)
1341
1342    if suspending_current_flow_run:
1343        # Exit this process so the run can be resubmitted later
1344        raise Pause()

Suspends a flow run by stopping code execution until resumed.

When suspended, the flow run will continue execution until the NEXT task is orchestrated, at which point the flow will exit. Any tasks that have already started will run until completion. When resumed, the flow run will be rescheduled to finish execution. In order suspend a flow run in this way, the flow needs to have an associated deployment and results need to be configured with the persist_results option.

Args: flow_run_id: a flow run id. If supplied, this function will attempt to suspend the specified flow run. If not supplied will attempt to suspend the current flow run. timeout: the number of seconds to wait for the flow to be resumed before failing. Defaults to 1 hour (3600 seconds). If the pause timeout exceeds any configured flow-level timeout, the flow might fail even after resuming. key: An optional key to prevent calling suspend more than once. This defaults to a random string and prevents suspends from running the same suspend twice. A custom key can be supplied for custom suspending behavior. wait_for_input: a subclass of RunInput or any type supported by Pydantic. If provided when the flow suspends, the flow will remain suspended until receiving the input before resuming. If the flow is resumed without providing the input, the flow will fail. If the flow is resumed with the input, the flow will resume and the input will be loaded and returned from this function.
